number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												This is a really fun teamplay-based game. It's not your usual kind of mmo where the amount you pay will determine how far you can get in the gameworld. Here you purchase the title once, and after that everything depends on your skills and your team's level of cooperation. Item shop items are purely cosmetic stuff, and some of them are given away for free during character progression anyway.  Working together is essential in this game, and one of the aspects that new players don't always understand first, which is why early gameplay can get difficult and full of lost battles. On the other hand, you can be extremely skillful from the start, depending on how fast you are willing to learn the game mechanics. There are many useful guides around, and most high level players will be more than happy to tell you everything you need to know.  It's most fun with microphone, especially if you wanna be a captain, but I know many great players who do very well and enjoy the game without mics. Some people say that you can't succeed in this without real life friends playing with you, but that's not true, most people here play and become friends without ever having met in real life.Yet, I'd recommend building an in-game friend list as soon as you start, adding people you had fun with, as the game gets more and more enjoyable and personal if you fight with familiar folks, and not always with completely new crew members.Gameplay and fighting system has a great variety and allows for numerous combinations. You can select ships, weapons, tools, maps, and all of these will determine the outcome. Because of that, preparation in lobbies can get long and tiresome sometimes, even boring, if you wanna play fast, but great victories always require great planning and preparation anyway, so consider it a part of gameplay to discuss strategies while you wait for teams to fill up. Don't forget that this is partly a strategy game, even though it offers action as well, and you gotta discuss tactics with your team at one point, and lobbies are the perfect places for that. Many people complain about the community and its rules being too restrictive, but most rules that the community guidelines include are perfectly normal and basic considerations asking for perfectly normal and basic human behaviour, such as "please don't spam and troll the global chat with profanity and/or racist comments because nobody is interested in them". The difference compared to other games is that here the community takes an active part in making sure that these guidelines are not just empty words on the game's website, but are actually kept in-game. Altogether this game is truly exciting, gives a new experience each time you fly, since nothing will be the same twice. Crews, captains, ships, maps, everything changes with each match, and that makes every battle feel unique. Also, for steampunk lovers, it's a must! :)

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												The game is way, way better than the metascore might suggest. I'm going to assume the low score is there partly because when you start the game aren't too many maps you can choose from, giving an impression of a limited game. As I've understood it, this is only so that you get practice on the easier levels before you go and navigate in the really dangerous ones. Once you reach lvl 4 in any crew role you'll get plenty more and the selection is about as numerous and varied as most FPS games, Killing Floor for example. These include a desert with component damaging dust clouds, a water temple zone, a foggy fjord and an ambush oriented canyon. When I got the game, there were only two play modes, but the devs have been adding new ones like Crazy King. There is also a good variety of ships, guns, and tools to use in different roles as a part of the crew so you'll have a different kind of match to play everytime you get to it.The graphics are good, the art style beautiful and the gameplay very polished. Starting players will be aware of only a few basic approaches to battle but the more you play the more you start to understand the potential for different tactics, using all of your guns to their full advantage, coordinating with other ships on your team etc. The community is one of the friendliest online gaming communities I've personally interacted with, most everyone is there to enjoy the game. As always, some players will give others a piece of their mind though. Still, as a new player I got good advice from those with more experience and no one was bashing me for making noob mistakes. Newbies are also restricted to play with other relatively new players (you can opt out from this if you wish), so you propably wont be completely decimated even when you're learning the ropes.The current game is just skirmish mode (different online battle modes) but the developers are looking to release an adventure mode in 2015; imagine an MMO world with airships, factions, trade and quests and you propably have the right general idea. With what they've managed to do so far I do have confidence that the adventure mode will be a good product as well. They already have the ship-to-ship combat nailed down, all they need is to expand the world they have already visioned and you can find info about on their site.If you've ever thought gliding through the skies on an airship would be awesome, if you enjoy tactical cooperative play, or if you enjoy steampunk aesthetics I can highly recommend this game - I've had some of my most engaging and fun gaming experiences on it. If the themes don't make you feel excited but you like online team based multiplayer games, Guns of Icarus is still a solid choice but you may want to hope for another sale to get it.

And you will get the jist.It is an amazing game to start seriouse on as it complements working togheter very very well.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												30 minutes of gameplay, so this is a ''first impression'' review.I love it.If you're a big fan of pvp type games ranging from strategy to fps's etc, this is definatly worth a shot.In my experience this is the first game of its type(?)You board airships and man turrets, pilot the ship or run around repairing♥♥♥♥♥♥You can design your own ship, character and advance in the various ''classes.''As a first impression I give it a 9/10.;;EDITNow I have a few more hours below my belt, my recommendation hasn't changed.Honestly, this game has grown on me.This game redefines teamwork in this genre. If your ship has a weak team mate you're basically ♥♥♥♥ed.It's a lot about communication, talking to your captain/ engineers/ gunners.So prior to this game I would recommend getting a microphone if you don't already have one.Also, there is talk of a single player campaign/ missions, which is planned to be released some time in 2015.Although this is a fairly new game, I haven't come across any serious bugs or glitches.The UI in the main menu is a tad confusing at first but once you learn to navigate the game there are a lot of cool features to take part it.Bounties, hunters, clans, costumes, ships, etc.This game will continue to be a favorite of mine for a long time to come.10/10

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Guns of Icarus Online is the little game that could. Please ignore the Metacritic score; this game has been updated and tweaked and polished and fixed and balanced beyond belief. If you played the original Guns of Icarus (not online), it was, well, pretty terrible. But it was a good proof of concept; even if it was torturous to play, you KNEW it could be epic with just a bit more effort and funding! Enter Guns of Icarus Online: the best team-centered game I've played in years. Sure, Team Fortress 2 might have the word "team" in its name, but in TF2, a skilled player can just run rampant on the enemy and perhaps swing the balance of the game. In other words, teamwork is beneficial but not required. In Super Monday Night Combat, team work is so essential that having one n00b on your team tolls the death knell every single game. SMNC is unforgiving and frustrating in that respect, which is why I abandoned it. But then there's Guns of Icarus Online. GOI works differently. It strikes the perfect balance between individual skill and teamwork. Teamwork is ESSENTIAL for victory, but having a new player on your ship won't guarantee defeat. The key is communication between the crew and the captain and between the captain and his fellow captains. This is not a twitch shooter. This is a thinking man's game. You choose your ship, you choose your tools, you choose your ammo, and you make the best of a hectic situation when the bullets start flying. The GOI community is one of (if not) the most mature I've played with; new players are welcomed aboard if they're willing to be patient and learn the mechanics of the game. The game features a variety of flyable ships and different classes and "class mods" to keep those ships sailing and shooting. The variety is fairly expansive, but there's still room for additional content, which developers Muse frequently add, free of charge. In a word, GOI deserves your time, your respect, your kind words, and your money. I got the game on sale on Steam in the spring of 2012 and, after realizing what a gem I'd purchased, I kick-started their Adventure Mode campaign for twice the retail price of the game and purchased in-game items from the devs to customize my character. Give Guns of Icarus Online a chance and you will not regret it. Make a cocktail, swab the poop deck, avast ye mateys, load your ammunition of choice, give 'em a FULL BROADSIDE, and then once you achieve RAMMING SPEED make another cocktail.  There's bad dudes out there that need their steampunk-powered clocks cleaned, and your time has come. See you in the skies!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												A marvelous game rooted in the teamwork and coordination of your crew. Short version:PROs-- Exciting gameplay and fleet battles-- Teamwork only makes said gameplay more exciting as you bark commands, call targets, and execute fleet maneuvers-- Great music-- Beautiful visuals-- Really friendly, helpful community-- Awesome game to play with friends (I bought a 4-pack during a sale two years ago and we all still play it)CONs-- Not very well optimized (I exceed specs, but can get a bit slow at times)-- Steep learning curve-- Mic basically required for effective teamwork (or at least 3/4 crew members need one, and all captains)-- More fun to play with friends. Not necessary though; hop in and make some new associates!Dramatic version:There are fewer things more exciting than hearing a chorus of,"Engines down, we're dead in the water!""On it, cap.""What's our target?""Fire on the Spire. Break their weapons, let's try to buy ourselves some time!"over the comms while two fleets of airships fill the air around you with flak, flechette, and fire. Fewer things more exciting than eliminating the entire enemey fleet without any friendly casualties because of a flawlessly executed formation. The sounds of crushing steel as airships collide; the sound of hammers hard at work repairing and fire extinguishers puffing.I love this game to pieces, and I love feeling like a Starfleet officer every time I play.The community is growing (slow but sure, hopefully it continues) thanks to the coming of Alliance. The gameplay is solid and the community is friendly, which more than makes up for the steep learning curve. If only Mountain Dew-infused tryhards played this game, it would be a nightmare, but for the most part people are welcoming of new players and eager to help them learn.I will say that a microphone is almost necessary. Failing that, fly with friends that you're on the phone or in the room with. Communication is imperative and you really will not have fun with this game if you aren't able to talk effectively.Overall, wonderful game. It's incredible and I'd recommend it to anybody who likes team-oriented games and/or steampunk.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Devs started begging players to write positive reviews to attract new players (90% discounts don't do the trick, huh?) 3 years after the release. Here it is.+ Game concept sounds perfect in theory. Four man crew has to cooperate to control a large airship and shoot down other airships? Who wouldn't like+ Devs however swiftly get you back on the ground, when you realise a concept has to be followed by an actual good bunch of programmers and designers to make a good game+ Devs ensure you get to see quite a lot of memorable funny moments, when you see how far from reality they are. They are completely unable to see the state of the game and its community.+ The community is constantly so hyped about every fart that comes out of the devs you'll get on the hype train easily too+ You get to find a new bug almost every week+ Every bug you report will be promised to be fixed+ For every bug that actually gets fixed you get one bug for free+ Devs are ignoring the game to work on a DLC! YAY!+ Competitive playerbase is so small you get to know everybody personally within a week or two+ Noobs go away immediately after getting stomped by better players, so the player base keeps a healthy number of a couple hundred players+ During the time I've been active in the game and its community (more than a year) we got tons of new content. One map, one gun and quite a load of promises of better tomorrows+ You never knew what is achievement farming until you tried it in Guns of Icarus+ You might find new friends here (no joke here, sry)- It takes quite a while to realise you can take the friends you got here and go play better games together- The joke "Blame Muse (devs)" gets old quite fast, when you realise you can actually blame them for everythingSo... if you got here and still wonder if you should buy it, I say: Go ahead! It's probably on sale right now and the price of one rollercoaster ride won't kill you. It might as well entertain you for longer but that's a stretch probably :)

												So I got this game. I played it once. I took a break and had food, good food mind you. Then I played it twice. Yet again I took a break. This time I slept. I slept for 9 hours. The alarm clock went off at 9AM but I turned it off. When I finally woke up at 9:04AM I had breakfast. It was a waffle. Some syrup was on it. I forgot to toast it though. The syrup was warm so it made up for it. By this time I was full. I stood up and pushed my chair in. Only enough so I could get up mind you. I washed the plate and my hands, with soap, mind you. It was lemon strawberry coconut soap, what will they think up next? luckily it was only 9:18Am now so I could still get to school before I was hungry again. I drove to school. Then I parked my car. I parked on the 3rd space from the left. Then I realized I forgot my pants. But it was ok because it was a dream. Then I woke up it was actually 9:05AM. Figuring I woudln't be able to make it too school before I was hungry I played the game a thrid time. Then I realized it was lunch. I had a taco. From Taco Bell. I had runs the next day. It ruined my toilet. I went to the doctor for my illness and I got a medicine for it. It tasted worse than baby vomit. baby vomit doesn't tast good. I then played the game a fourth time. This time I stopped and watched the TV. Nothing good was on it. Thats because I dusted though. Normally I have a really cool action figure of the pope on the top right corner. Channel 45 had a marathon of info-mercials which I quite enjoyed.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												If you don't want to read the rest, then the sum up, yes, its a fantastic game.There are many reasons why you ought to buy it and if you have 10 minutes to kill, keep on reading.It is a player verses player featuring airships if you can't tell by the pictures yet. Three main roles you can try are Pilot (for those that fancy command structure and flight simulators) Gunner (for those that like shooting games, self explanatory) and Engineer (for those that like neither, but time management games are close enough). The classes allow you to have more items that pertain to your class choice. In example, an engineer would have 3 items from the engineer gear, and one of each from the pilot and gunner selections. It's simple and allows customization to play style. Point is, there is something there for anyone. When starting out, the amount of relevant gear is the same no matter the level. As in, a level 10 gunner has the same abilities as a level 1. The only difference between the two are the badges (which are only aesthetic) and the free costume bits (also only cosmetic, and can be bought in a store). The levels amount to how much time you've played. You level by fulfilling achievements, and that in itself will start easy but will get hard as time goes on. Like any game, you will need to pratice to be great, but there is not an unfair gear bonus due to level.***Edit*** After a few patches, you gain levels through experience now. Achievements are now XP boosters and bragging rights.There are a wide selection of ship types, which you can choose the weaponry, add dyes and themes in order to have more of a custom look as well. The customization is fairly new and limited, but to be honest you'll be blowing each other up enough its not really as much as an issue. Each ship has their ups and downs (see what I did there) from speed, survivability, how much firepower it can have and so on.  The guns are also all unique in their own abilities, what ammo works best with what outcome and so on. You need 4 people to each ship, at least one a pilot. Other slots can be filled with AI. Its not perfect, by all means. The graphics are neither good nor bad really. Customization, while present, is a bit limited. The AI can be a bit hard to wrangle (the only thing I've seen them to well is stationary shooting when in range, other wise tend to be in the way). It can get a bit laggy, especially if the server is hosted by a country different then yours (that's kinda expected though). It can be daunting to start a game as that you need all captains to be ready and this may take a while if the online player base is low. It can be a bit clannish, so I recommend doing some research and join one or play with friends as that it's a lot more fun that way.  However, if you are new and politely ask people on chat, most are more then happy to give advice. There are also tutorials that cover the basics for all roles. I also recommend a headset with a mic. A lot of the time there will be orders issued, and while the in game chat system can be a bit wobbly, its best to have a mic nonetheless.I will note that the community is some of the cleanest I have ever seen . You can't escape trolls, this a given to any online gaming, but the majority of the regulars have no tolerance towards indecency. There is a report option and many are happy to use it against racist, sexist, or just indecent remarks. As a female gamer, my opinion more often then not is valued the same, and this is incredibly refreshing. A lot of girls are more willing to talk because the community tries to foster a positive outlook, which I sincerely hope stays. Muse, the team behind the game, can be spotted playing it themselves and take an active look in their own product, which is pretty nice. But what really has me interested is the Adventure Mode that is scheduled to come out. It is said to have a co-op story line that everyone is really looking forward to (their website has far more). Over all, just buy this game for you and a few buddies. Really, steam punk pirates should be reason enough.

When it comes to my list of favorite things ever, Guns of Icarus is on that list and remains to be the only game I can fully enjoy again and again. 10/10

												A really charming and fantastic game for the cost. The concepts can take people some getting used to, but the game really does offer an experience that most games do not. It has all the downfalls that come with being a competitive game, but the benefits seem ten fold over MOBAs and FPSs in the sense that when you win there is a truly gratifying team experience almost every match. You feel like the captain of a ship, you feel the pressure of being an engineer as the ship begins to burn, and you feel satisfaction in well-timed and placed volleys made at the gunner position. It is one of the few games I've ever played where I didn't think the game was balanced to how people deal damage.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Not for the "OH MA GAWD ITS MOVING SHEWT IT" kind of people.And that’s a good thing! Because this beautiful game actually requires you to:-THINK-COMMUNITCATE-BE A TEAMSet in a jaw dropping steam-punk style world with plenty of ships, maps, and tools to make it not only authentic, but highly impressive for an air-ship combat environment.Pros:-RIDICULOUSLY easy to pick up and learn the roles/tools/ships/maps. This makes the learning curves simple when synergized with the achievement progress. Any class can do anything on the ship, but may access certain tools when doing their respective job. You have a: Pilot, gunner, and Engineer. All which are essential to every ship -Interesting idea. -Though very few customization, each thing proves it purpose accordnig to how you fly (assuming you’re a captain of the crew)This game needs time to invest. Games are decently long and offer a whole new experience to FPS. Aside from Steampunk themed-skybox sexiness, the core gameplay is without a doubt fun; No matter what class you play. The slow game play requires you to think, as mentioned before. This maybe a turn off to A LOT OF PEOPLE, considering many game industries are now aiming for ways to make gameplay faster. Cons:-The Achievement system is in a style that asks for repetition of certain things, yet get progressively more obscure later on as our progress. While it aids in learning the game, it maybe be difficult to pull off certain things along. Leaving people like me who’ve flown thousands of matches, seem a little behind.-Slow game play. That will be a major turn off. Though I look down upon it being a problem to begin with, it is what is, and I know most people will complain about it.-May be uninteresting and boring after a few days on it. The game doesn’t offer that much in terms of gameplay or items (though they will have content every once in a while like most games). Combining this with the speed of the game may make some people fall asleep.This game has a possibility to be extremely boring to many. There are also minor bug/glitches (which all games have), and this ultimately turns the game into a waste of your money; especially when combined with its slowness. That seems to be the only problem (aside from no one wanting to be pilot). Again, if you’re looking for in-action heart pounding games, this isn’t for you. Otherwise, I say get it 

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Great steampunk themed game that heavily focuses on teamplay. The basics are rather simple and easy to get into if you get someone to quickly explain to you all the important stuff, which is easy thanks to the friendly community GoIO has. (Second option is doing the tutorials which are frankly boring, but somewhat neccessary if option one fails.)Mastering the game is whole other story, that takes thousands and thousands of games. The simple things you learn at the start get more and more complicated. You'll need to improve your aim as a gunner, get the timing spot on as an engineer and finally tactically outwit enemies as a pilot.In the first few battles you probably won't have any idea what's going on - that's ok, get through it, it's worth it.The major flaw of this game is its small playerbase that continues to shrink every week. The lack of players means the game can often be unbalanced and therefore unfair to the newcomers who of course don't stick as a result of one sided matches.OUTDATED: Developers don't really help, they somewhat continue to ruin the game more and more with every patch. As they mostly ignore player feedback and base their nonsense balance decisions on statistics without actually playing the game. Their efforts to try to make the game more simple to lure in and retain new folk only lead to old "veteran" players to leave the game instead.EDIT: Developers finally started listening to player feedback bringing long needed community patches. The game seems to be heading into the right direction once again.It would be a great game with more players, now it's mostly just a painful experience.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Outstanding first-person game where you are either a pilot, gunner or engineer on a 4-person steampunk airship with various weapons (gatling guns, rocket launchers, flamethrowers and more).  You play in matches where a team of 2 ships fights another 2-ship team, or in larger 3v3 or 4v4 matches, set in beautiful 3D maps in various settings (arctic, desert, ruined urban landscape, canyons).There is a bit of a learning curve at first, becoming familiar with the various ship types, rangng from the speedy Squid (which I like to think of as a "sports car with machine guns"), to the ponderous but powerful Galleon.  You also have to become familiar with the different repair tools, pilot tools, ammunition types and weapons.This is very much a game where teamwork and communication are key - the pilot has to position the ship to work with teammates to attack enemies, the gunners mainly shoot weapons, and the engineers keep the ship alive, while also firing weapons as needed.  If the crew (and team) does not work together smoothly, disaster is likely to be the result.I've played this game for over two years, at least several days per week, so you can tell I really like it, and recommend it to anyone interested in this genre.  Don't be discouraged at first when you go down in flames and your ship parts decorate the landscape, we all start somewhere :)The people in the community are generally very helpful to new players, especially if they have good attitudes about learning new things and listen to good advice (which is true of almost anything in life, really.)So come aboard and see what's going on!

How it is different is because you are a guy in a ship, eather reparing, pioliting, or shooting the pot side guns. This game is havely set of team mates working together to win. I you doin't work as a team you will get shot down fast. The game has a nice steampunk feel to it,  It gives you the feel of ship Vs ship combat, without feeling tacky. It reminds me of a 1st/3rd person Online FTL game. And I love FLT. SO that is a good pluse, but my main gripe is that the online servers are just laggy for me. But that might just be my internet. Is the game good, yes, should you wait for a price drop, yes, is this game better with freinds, absolutly. It is not a must have, but it is a great game.P.S. Right is starborn, Left is port. Lern this

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												A really charming and fantastic game for the cost. The concepts can take people some getting used to, but the game really does offer an experience that most games do not. It has all the downfalls that come with being a competitive game, but the benefits seem ten fold over MOBAs and FPSs in the sense that when you win there is a truly gratifying team experience almost every match. You feel like the captain of a ship, you feel the pressure of being an engineer as the ship begins to burn, and you feel satisfaction in well-timed and placed volleys made at the gunner position. It is one of the few games I've ever played where I didn't think the game was balanced to how people deal damage.

												I definitely recommend this game, though it definitely has a learning curve to it, and there are many ins and outs that are to be learned throughout playing, the community is pretty nice, I can't say everyone is perfectly nice, but there is a large portion which are ready and willing to help, and most are plenty willing to offer advice in lobbies and mid-game.Being a game with plenty of updates that happen every month or so, there are some changes to adjust to and re-balancing, but even when starting out if some things seem impossible to combat, there is usually a way to combat it, which is why it's always nice to ask around for advice and so on.Other than that, it is a really fun and enjoyable game, especially if you make some friends in the community or get some friends to join in with you, the graphics are amazing(so long you have a PC to power it), and great game mechanics. Also a great part is that every ship, and class as well as tools are available without requiring DLC or microtransactions. Really the only microtransactions are costmetics(ship and character), which just adds to your ability to make yourself stand out if you wish. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												One of the most teamwork demanding games I have played, with a very active and involved developer team. Airship combat, from 2v2 to 4v4, 4 players per ship consisting of a mixture of pilots, gunners and engineers, attempting to work together within the ship itself and further teamwork with their allies ships as well. A Multitude of ship designs, guns, ammunitions and crew tools make it possible to play in a vast variety of manners and no two games are ever truly the same.The graphics aren't best in the buisness but they are still very nice to look at, views across the horizon are especially beautiful. With a steampunk setting there is a familiar aesthetic to it all, with plenty of cosmetic unlocks / purchases providing a variety of character options as well as some ship customization.As for the bad points, it's one biggest flaw sadly is that the playerbase is so small, as almost all of it's gameplay issues could be solved by simply having a larger pool of players to draw from. The two main complaints players seem to have is that games can take a while to begin (players join a lobby to assemble crews) and that the teams can often be rather uneven, both would be solveable if it had more players for the matchmaker to draw from. It's not it's only issue, but it's the only one that causes problems.The community at present is very small frequently meeting the same players, and as a result is very friendly, most of the veterans are more than willing to help teach newer players the ropes. For anyone wishing to start I would recommend doing so during a steam sale and/or weekend, as there will be more activity allowing for a novice-only match to fill up and less of a steep curve.Edit: A year later I've come back to play again, game is still fun as ever with a friendly community (mostly, you'll never get everyone), few more novices around. The only negative to say after this time is that the developers haven't really changed much in Skirmish due to their focus on upcoming PvE mode "Alliance".

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Outstanding first-person game where you are either a pilot, gunner or engineer on a 4-person steampunk airship with various weapons (gatling guns, rocket launchers, flamethrowers and more).  You play in matches where a team of 2 ships fights another 2-ship team, or in larger 3v3 or 4v4 matches, set in beautiful 3D maps in various settings (arctic, desert, ruined urban landscape, canyons).There is a bit of a learning curve at first, becoming familiar with the various ship types, rangng from the speedy Squid (which I like to think of as a "sports car with machine guns"), to the ponderous but powerful Galleon.  You also have to become familiar with the different repair tools, pilot tools, ammunition types and weapons.This is very much a game where teamwork and communication are key - the pilot has to position the ship to work with teammates to attack enemies, the gunners mainly shoot weapons, and the engineers keep the ship alive, while also firing weapons as needed.  If the crew (and team) does not work together smoothly, disaster is likely to be the result.I've played this game for over two years, at least several days per week, so you can tell I really like it, and recommend it to anyone interested in this genre.  Don't be discouraged at first when you go down in flames and your ship parts decorate the landscape, we all start somewhere :)The people in the community are generally very helpful to new players, especially if they have good attitudes about learning new things and listen to good advice (which is true of almost anything in life, really.)So come aboard and see what's going on!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												If you don't want to read the rest, then the sum up, yes, its a fantastic game.There are many reasons why you ought to buy it and if you have 10 minutes to kill, keep on reading.It is a player verses player featuring airships if you can't tell by the pictures yet. Three main roles you can try are Pilot (for those that fancy command structure and flight simulators) Gunner (for those that like shooting games, self explanatory) and Engineer (for those that like neither, but time management games are close enough). The classes allow you to have more items that pertain to your class choice. In example, an engineer would have 3 items from the engineer gear, and one of each from the pilot and gunner selections. It's simple and allows customization to play style. Point is, there is something there for anyone. When starting out, the amount of relevant gear is the same no matter the level. As in, a level 10 gunner has the same abilities as a level 1. The only difference between the two are the badges (which are only aesthetic) and the free costume bits (also only cosmetic, and can be bought in a store). The levels amount to how much time you've played. You level by fulfilling achievements, and that in itself will start easy but will get hard as time goes on. Like any game, you will need to pratice to be great, but there is not an unfair gear bonus due to level.***Edit*** After a few patches, you gain levels through experience now. Achievements are now XP boosters and bragging rights.There are a wide selection of ship types, which you can choose the weaponry, add dyes and themes in order to have more of a custom look as well. The customization is fairly new and limited, but to be honest you'll be blowing each other up enough its not really as much as an issue. Each ship has their ups and downs (see what I did there) from speed, survivability, how much firepower it can have and so on.  The guns are also all unique in their own abilities, what ammo works best with what outcome and so on. You need 4 people to each ship, at least one a pilot. Other slots can be filled with AI. Its not perfect, by all means. The graphics are neither good nor bad really. Customization, while present, is a bit limited. The AI can be a bit hard to wrangle (the only thing I've seen them to well is stationary shooting when in range, other wise tend to be in the way). It can get a bit laggy, especially if the server is hosted by a country different then yours (that's kinda expected though). It can be daunting to start a game as that you need all captains to be ready and this may take a while if the online player base is low. It can be a bit clannish, so I recommend doing some research and join one or play with friends as that it's a lot more fun that way.  However, if you are new and politely ask people on chat, most are more then happy to give advice. There are also tutorials that cover the basics for all roles. I also recommend a headset with a mic. A lot of the time there will be orders issued, and while the in game chat system can be a bit wobbly, its best to have a mic nonetheless.I will note that the community is some of the cleanest I have ever seen . You can't escape trolls, this a given to any online gaming, but the majority of the regulars have no tolerance towards indecency. There is a report option and many are happy to use it against racist, sexist, or just indecent remarks. As a female gamer, my opinion more often then not is valued the same, and this is incredibly refreshing. A lot of girls are more willing to talk because the community tries to foster a positive outlook, which I sincerely hope stays. Muse, the team behind the game, can be spotted playing it themselves and take an active look in their own product, which is pretty nice. But what really has me interested is the Adventure Mode that is scheduled to come out. It is said to have a co-op story line that everyone is really looking forward to (their website has far more). Over all, just buy this game for you and a few buddies. Really, steam punk pirates should be reason enough.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Very fun game!The game has a first person perspective, and you play as either a pilot, engineer, or gunner. Pilots control the ship's three dimensional movement through a myriad of systems. They use lift to direct their movement up and down (w+s) and engines to turn left or right and to move forward, or backward. The speed of forward and backward movement can be controlled with the throttle (r+f). They have a choice of items that alters the ship's capabilities for a short period of time, usually at the damage of a relevant system. There are a lot of choices - moonshine in the engines for a quick boost; a chute vent to help you lose altitude quickly; tar barrels that make smog which damages ships that pass through it - and a good few more. It's the pilot's job to ensure the crew stays on task, in position, and alive.Engineers keep the ships running. The major systems of a ship - engines, balloon, weapons, and hull armor - can all be damaged during conflict. These systems will individually shut down to the detriment of the ship's crew. No engines means no movement, and  no balloon means you crash into the ground. No weapons means you can't defend yourself, and no hull armor means your ship's health will begin to take direct damage until either the armor is repaired or you disintegrate. Engineers can bring three repair items with them which repair the ship's components in different ways, but they can also bring ammo, so in those rare times when you're not getting shot you can adequately man a nearby gun. It's good to know which gun(s) on a ship you are likely to be using as an engineer and bring the complimentary ammo.Gunners are simplier, and some people would argue unnecessary. Gunners have the unique ability to bring three types of ammo, rather than the single slot restricted to the engineer. This means that there are certain situations where a gunner is helpful, but those times are honestly quite rare. However, I find it is common on the small to medium sized ships that three engineers are neither necessary nor overly helpful; conveniently, all but the largest of ships have most of their vital systems within a relatively small running distance. So with only two engineers necessary to keep the ship moving that means you'll likely have one crew member always on a gun anyway. Even when that person needs to jump off their gun to do emergency repairs, the only engineering item they would usually need is a spanner or a mallet. So while a gunner doesn't necessarily bring huge advantages to a group (I hope to see this change), I disagree with the notion that they bring any direct disadvantage to a crew.The game has seven ships currently, all with vastly different layouts, stats, and playstyles. From my time playing it all seems relatively "balanced"; it's important to know what your ship is good at and play to those strengths. A Squid with its measly mass and three medium gun slots won't be able to stand toe-to-toe with a Galleon - a hulking double decker monstrosity with two large gun slots on either broadside - for very long. Solution? Use the Squid's astronomically higher speed and mobility to do strafe runs on the Galleon or stay behind it so that you only have its rear gun slot to worry about. All seven ships have such varied roles, and while some are surely favorited and some fallen into a more niche category, all command their own respect and strategy to compete with.There are microtransactions in the game, I believe I spent somewhere around $10 on this game during my time playing it. With that in-game currency I purchased an outfit for my character with paint and accessories for my ships. Since then I have not needed to purchase anything as there is nothing but cosmetic options in the store. I think the prices were relatively fair and I had no complications using steam wallet to purchase the currency.Overall I would rate this game a solid 8/10. If you can grab it on a 75% off sale, and you like the style of game, it would be silly not to get it. That being said, the game is much better if you can play it with friends. The game's interface is very accomidating to this; it has its own friends list, crew system, and matchmaking. Communication is vital in this game, and unfortunately I have heard whisperings that the public group community in this game is as bad as it is in every public grouped competitive game. But what makes friends better than a little gunship warfare? YAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARTLDR; 8/10, blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up on a gunship with your buddies

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Guns of Icarus Online is a steampunk airship combat game. As a pilot, I choose and customise an airship (you get all the airships when you buy the game, no airship DLC nonsense) and either wait for a crew or invite some friends. There can be up to three crew members, and if nobody shows up then AIs do the job (badly, of course, since they're hard to communicate with).Crew members will be one of two chosen classes: gunner or engineer. Gunners man the guns, engineers repair - in theory. Anyone can man a gun, and engineers often will do so when nothing needs repairing.And now to what I actually think. It's a fun game, with great aesthetics - when I go to ram an airship (and I always end up ramming), I can see the crew of the other ship. They're so tiny. They look like little ants. I like ants. Have you ever seen a close-up picture of an ant? Yeah, ants are cool. Ant-Man had some pet ants, I think. He could shrink, too.*Ahem* Anyway. Your character is customiseable, though most stuff requires you to buy (or design!) items from the store. So either your crew or ships that are really really close will see it.There's a few issues, though - many people seem to be unable to refrain from naming their ship something ridiculous, like "Yoda's Virginity". I had to give orders to my crew like "Quick, after The Yoda's Virginity!" or "Destroy Yoda's Virginity!". I felt quite silly.Also, my ship is haunted. An AI keeps appearing and just charging right off the side and vanishing. It's a funny glitch.In conclusion, it's a steampunk game about airships and the airships explode with fireworks when they die. You should buy it if you like airships, but everyone likes airships, so you should probably buy it.

												Guns of Icarus combines steampunk themes with airships and firepower. If you are a fan of shooting, flying or machines then you will likely enjoy this game. It's something that's best played in doses but even more than a year later I'm still coming back to it.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Recommendation for Guns of Icarus Online.PROS:-Game is easy to understand in the beginning.-Multiplayer is easy and mostly accessible to all players.-Character Progression is endorsed.-Easy to navigate UI for the player.CONS:-Clans have no reason to be used overall.-Character Progression is tideous sometimes to upgrade.-Sense of playing the same thing every game with no changes.Notes:-Playing Online with randoms is not as fun as playing with friends.-You may choose to level up 1 job, but then in-game not be able to be that job as it is already taken.-Clans are contradictory to the fact there is no easy way to do clanvsclan.Rating:8.2/10Overall:I would recommend Guns Of Icarus Online to players who have a lot of time to level up their character, has a lot of friends on frequently who own the game, and if you straight up like character progression and teamwork.

So while a gunner doesn't necessarily bring huge advantages to a group (I hope to see this change), I disagree with the notion that they bring any direct disadvantage to a crew.The game has seven ships currently, all with vastly different layouts, stats, and playstyles. From my time playing it all seems relatively "balanced"; it's important to know what your ship is good at and play to those strengths. A Squid with its measly mass and three medium gun slots won't be able to stand toe-to-toe with a Galleon - a hulking double decker monstrosity with two large gun slots on either broadside - for very long. Solution? Use the Squid's astronomically higher speed and mobility to do strafe runs on the Galleon or stay behind it so that you only have its rear gun slot to worry about. All seven ships have such varied roles, and while some are surely favorited and some fallen into a more niche category, all command their own respect and strategy to compete with.There are microtransactions in the game, I believe I spent somewhere around $10 on this game during my time playing it. With that in-game currency I purchased an outfit for my character with paint and accessories for my ships. Since then I have not needed to purchase anything as there is nothing but cosmetic options in the store. I think the prices were relatively fair and I had no complications using steam wallet to purchase the currency.Overall I would rate this game a solid 8/10. If you can grab it on a 75% off sale, and you like the style of game, it would be silly not to get it. That being said, the game is much better if you can play it with friends. The game's interface is very accomidating to this; it has its own friends list, crew system, and matchmaking. Communication is vital in this game, and unfortunately I have heard whisperings that the public group community in this game is as bad as it is in every public grouped competitive game. But what makes friends better than a little gunship warfare? YAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARTLDR; 8/10, blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up on a gunship with your buddies

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												One of the most teamwork demanding games I have played, with a very active and involved developer team. Airship combat, from 2v2 to 4v4, 4 players per ship consisting of a mixture of pilots, gunners and engineers, attempting to work together within the ship itself and further teamwork with their allies ships as well. A Multitude of ship designs, guns, ammunitions and crew tools make it possible to play in a vast variety of manners and no two games are ever truly the same.The graphics aren't best in the buisness but they are still very nice to look at, views across the horizon are especially beautiful. With a steampunk setting there is a familiar aesthetic to it all, with plenty of cosmetic unlocks / purchases providing a variety of character options as well as some ship customization.As for the bad points, it's one biggest flaw sadly is that the playerbase is so small, as almost all of it's gameplay issues could be solved by simply having a larger pool of players to draw from. The two main complaints players seem to have is that games can take a while to begin (players join a lobby to assemble crews) and that the teams can often be rather uneven, both would be solveable if it had more players for the matchmaker to draw from. It's not it's only issue, but it's the only one that causes problems.The community at present is very small frequently meeting the same players, and as a result is very friendly, most of the veterans are more than willing to help teach newer players the ropes. For anyone wishing to start I would recommend doing so during a steam sale and/or weekend, as there will be more activity allowing for a novice-only match to fill up and less of a steep curve.Edit: A year later I've come back to play again, game is still fun as ever with a friendly community (mostly, you'll never get everyone), few more novices around. The only negative to say after this time is that the developers haven't really changed much in Skirmish due to their focus on upcoming PvE mode "Alliance".

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												I was once asked by a friend of mine to describe this game and what it was all about. I opened my mouth as my tongue started firing blanks. I had no idea how to describe this game. I thought for all of about a minute and then my mouth painstakingly howled, "Pirates of the Sky!" and then I fell over from my brain overworking itself. I can only imagine how this is going to turn out...Guns of Icarus: Online (henceforth to be called GoI:O for the rest of this review) is Multiplayer only, Team based, Matchmaking, Ship flying...*inhale*...damn thats a lot, created by a development team called MUSE and damn do they have something with this game. I found this game way back in the olden days of I believe March of 2013 when a youtuber by the name of Markiplier participated in a Polaris  organized match with several other youtubers and members of the development team. I remember wondering to myself, "Why would a character of Greek Mythology need a firearm?" Several reasons actually, but the point is that my jaw disconnected and hit the floor.The game takes place in a post-apocalyp-stick type world that for once didn't end in either the usual Nuclear blast, zombie attack or act of God. This world tore itself and new fecal defecator in a giant, global war that has divided the world into several large, powerful and very 1910s nations and has created new weapons of war; this including your valient war horses. In this game you fly ships. No, that isn't an oxymoron, you actually FLY. SHIPS! These ships are essentially the Black Pearl meets Hindenburg, but with more firepower and personality then Chuck Norris' beard. And each ship is drastically different in playstyle, armnament and design.On this subject of gamplay, the gameplay of GoI:O is like nothing I have ever played before, but for the sake of you I will divide my thoughts into the the three classes: Pilot, Engineer, and Gunner. Lets start with the easiest one, the Gunner. His or Her main job is to the fire the guns on the ship (No ♥♥♥♥♥e, Herr Sherlock!) and not much else. However, this roll is a highly specialized one in that the gunner needs to know how to fire EVERY guns there is, which is a Herculian task considering that each gun is different and travels differently in the world. Some weapons are really good and range while others just have too much of an arch to fire accurately or just explode in mid air.Speaking of explosions, lets talk about Engineers. If you like stressful work environments where your sole job is to run around like a Banshee repairing things like mad, this is for you! Okay, I'm being dramatic here, but the Engineer has what I believe to be the most important and difficult job. They are the all-arounders, constantly moving about the ship checking the various components of the ship and filling jobs as they come up with their wide assortment of tools. They will frequently be called upon to go on full repairs, fire weapons, spot enemy ships, and even take the helm depending on who you fly with. It is one of the most fun, difficult, and rewarding positions you can have in this game.Finally we come to my favorite position: Piloting. Flying these babys around in normal conditions is challenging enough depending on what map you play, but flying under fire takes some serious cajones, as the Latin peoples call it. As I said before, each ship has its own different playstyle so it is easy for up and coming Captains to find their fit or even prefer multiple ships over others (Pyramidion Master Race), so the creativity from all the different tactics for flying each ship and  tools to gain the advantage over your enemies through smoke screens, impact bumpers or even magical "Take me up now" fuel, really astounds me and manages to always make me wonder, "How the hell did he do that?!"Not only does this game offer a straight up Team Deathmatch in 2v2, 3v3 or 4v4 gamemodes in ship vs. ship combat, but it also has a very difficult game mode of capturing differnt territories on the map and collecting resources until you reach the max cap of points and win. Sadly, this is the only other gamemode, which really sucks because I'm sure Muse has some really awesome ideas in the pipe. However, the awesome beauty and detail of the maps that makes you feel like your on an epic journey kinda makes up for this. Plus there is going to be an MMO release of this game later in 2014, so hey, who am I to complain. A real♥♥♥♥♥ thats what I'd be.Probably the most commendable thing that Muse has done is the community they have created in this game. Without a doubt it is the best on Steam. There, I said. Go ahead and argue with me, but I haven't seen a single rude or idiotic person on this game until Pewdiepie attrached his fans to the game. Most of the community is very helpful and understanding to new players and even the developers remain active in the game, not just on forums, but actually playing the game with people and constantly asking what they could add or make better. They've even set up 'Community Ambassadors' that serve to keep the chat clean and game experience the best it can be. There are even several active clans that hold scheduled matches against eachother like you would see on a Starcraft twitch stream. *Ahem* go clan lol!All in all, this game is so fun and creative that I don't think I could ever write a proper review for it. My best suggestion would be to play the game for yourself and just let the excellence rain all over you. Or is that Moonshine?Anyways, Guns of Icarus: Online gets 8 mallets to the hull out of 10.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												While it is a little sparse nowadays, player-wise, Guns of Icarus is an excellent game where your motley crew of misfits (which may be in the form of your friends) go up into the skies in your sky boat, and shoot down other sky boats.There IS a lot more nuance to that simple statement. While attempting to kaboom other ships, your crew must repair your ship before it gets kaboomed. Engineers are the best at repair, while Gunners do the kabooming. Pilots, the third class, are the... well, the pilots of your sky boat, and also are normally the captain of the sky boat. Pilots get fancy things which can change how the ship flies, in exchange, when you use it, your engineer yells at you and your skyboat's engine or balloon takes some damage.This game is a great pickup, if you have friends to play with. Due to the sparce playerbase, I wouldn't advise buying this game for the solo play.Grab a few friends, take to the skies, and shoot down some sky boats, and laugh once everything goes horribly wrong.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Quite the delightful co-op game, between you and three other friends. No role appears greater than the other, and the game is balanced with plenty of options for crewmates to try out: different tools, different ships, and different weapons, including cannons, guns, and flamethrowers. Once you crash, it really feels as if a team effort to charge into the next battle to make up for losses; and once the other ship goes down leaving a trail of black smoke across your deck, it's the most satisfying feeling in the world. I wish there were more steampunk games that existed out there, and even if you're not much for the lifestyle, the gameplay is solid still immensely enjoyable. It provides an excellent break from all of the first/third person shooters that flood our gaming market today. Your best bet is to grab this game while on sale along with friends if you'd like to try it out, but not 100% sure.

But even as it is now, it's great, but it won't appeal to everyone.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												PROS- Focus on tactics over twitch reactions- High customisablity- Good community- FUN- High replayability- Graphics and Sound are well polishedCONS- Very addictive- Menu system needs better explanation for newbies, but not too difficult to get the hang ofTruth be told, this is easily one of the better Multiplayer offerings available on Steam !For a brief overview, this game is all about team planning and strategy. But where other games focus on twitch reactions and the like, Guns of Icarus is more of a deliberate slow burner. Every move you make is critical, but a quick trigger finger is less important than setting up where you are going next. Once you get in close and all hell breaks loose, it is rare to feel cheated in the event of destruction - it just means you have to regroup and try a new approach. Half the fun is in the endlessly replayable variance of trying to overcome different captains and their new tricks while maneuvering between the canyons, wrecks and sandstorms of the map.Even before you get into an actual match, there is a huge amount of customisation and planning you can undertake to provide subtle advantages (and disadvantages). Not only do the three classes (Pilot, Engineer, Gunner) each have special 'stamina' abilities dedicated to the left shift key which range from enhanced ship mobility, quicker reloading and faster in person sprinting, but they also have access to extra slots for their respective class items that dictate what they can do. Engineers can choose from various repair tools, Gunners from a variety of ammo types and Pilots can pick from a number of ship-based 'buff' abilities that can help maneuver in times of trouble. This, coupled with the large number of cool airships each with their own unique configurations of customisable weapon placements, gives the entire game an impressive level of tactical feel few others match. Do you go for the long range barrages of a Hwacha-armed Galleon, or hope to outmaneuver it with a zippy flamer-equipped Squid? The community itself is welcoming and pleasantly receptive to banter - I have had no trouble with anyone, and though not everyone has mics there is a comprehensive set of commands issuable via the 'V' key to cover almost all situations. If you DO get a team full of mics, though, then it turns into a joyful mad cacophany of communication as gunners call out targets out of arc and engineers shout out for help putting out engine fires while the Pilot converses with the other captains calling out battle plans.All in all, it is definitely worth the money whether you are just looking for a fresh multiplayer experience or you are after something deeper and far more unique than available elsewhere. The 4-pack is a steal, and even more so when it is on sale.Grab some friends and rule the high skies !

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
A Powerful and Immersive Cooperative ExperienceImagine flying your very own Airship the way you want it. Imagine you and your friends cooperating together as a fully-functioning crew doing various tasks (controlling the helm, manning the guns, repairing engines, etc) working together as one to thwart the opposing crew, just like organs in a body working together to achieve an objective. Imagine your adrenaline rush when you are busy fixing the hull of your ship as the enemy closes in starboard side and no one is manning the gun and you enthusiastically called for help while the captain directs someone to repair the balloon due to losing altitude. Imagine working together with 2 other crew teams against 3 opposing teams (12v12) in the midst of a Sandstorm, imagine a game full of adrenaline, tactics and chaos.That game is Guns of Icarus Online.If there is any game that tests your cooperation, look no further. The graphics are deeply immersive with various maps and airships, coupled with amazing music that warrants you into the Steampunk Universe. You can choose among 3 roles (Captain, Engineer and Gunner), which gives you added advantage performing specific tasks. As the ship requires someone to steer, gunners to man the gun, engineers to fix ship components in the midst of a battle, everyone will have things to do at all times and you will have to do it in tandem with the other players.There are currently a total of 7 ships available to choose from (3 for Novice matches), and the fact that each ships has a different layout as well as stats really gives each one a very different feel and a very large-scale of depth for any team albeit anyone to master.My own experience was a blast as I played this game along with three other RL friends, we have switched various ships and realized how extensive this game was as each of these ships give a very different feel. We found one that works though, and performance really showed when we decided to use this ship. Overall we are playing non-novice matches regularly and each session are always packed with high amounts of adrenaline and gameplay depth.Negative pointsTo be fair, there are some quirks and negative points if you really want to pick and prod, here are some minor negative points that we pick up if you are really concerned:- Open information prior to match is open to abuse where dirty abusive players (or those who want to win no matter what) will customize their loadout to counter yours.- Player customization is very minimal, but perhaps this is due to their business model.- In-game description does not really match and is often misleading, to really understand each of the weapons/bullets/ships, it is critical to have a hands-on experience in each of them. Despite that, overall this game has totally blew our mind as it totally went above and beyond our expectationsTL/DRThis piece of gem has flown under my radar for so long and judging by the fact that none of my friends from various gaming communities has ever mentioned this game is simply ludicrous. This game is an absolute blast! If you have friends (4 as a team), please buy it already.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Guns of Icarus, a game-simulator of REPAIRTHEHULLYOUIDIOTS.Rather unique game with various game modes. As you start with the Novice level (levels before lvl 8 of any class) you are given simple ships to control ("Goldfish", "Pyramideon" and "Junker"). Every ship has their own unique pros or cons so it depends on what kind or ship you choose for your team. Each ship has around 3 engines, 1 hull and a balloon, as well as the guns. The hull is the most important part as it works like your armor which can be repaired. If this armor is down your ship takes damage, the ship damage can not be repaired.A team can be max up to 3 ships with their own crew. And the only way to contact the other crew in-game is either by having captains speak in their private voice chat or in the team text chat that entire team can see.It doesn't have next-gen graphics but all the locations and views are beautiful so I give it 8/10.There are 3 classes to play: Captain, Gunner and Engineer. All of the classes can do eachother's roles, but without being able to use "Boost" ability on things they are not meant to be doing (such as boost for the ship [captain], boost for reload speed [gunner] or boost for run speed [engineer]). Each class also has 1 item/perk that is used for either guns or the ship or for the repairing (depending on which class they do NOT belong to).There is only 1 captain in the crew. His main priority is to control the ship and use his perks to give it buffs for the cost of damage per second to engines or balloons, some for the cost of movement priorities.The gunner's task is to... well, wield guns. He has 3 perks that he can use, each of them has specific affection on the gun's priorities, such as attack speed, clip size, damage and projectile speed. He can also repair stuff but less efficiently (given he has only 1 tool that he can use for repairing)Engineer is the hero of your crew and possibly the second gunner if has good affiliations with the guns and his single perk that he has. If there were to be a comparison between a moba and Guns of Icarus, engineer is your support. Engineer wields 3 different tools. Each tool has their own priority for fixing and extinguishing fire. Engineer's tools are rather different from perks of Gunner and Captain. His tools either repair a big amount of health but have a big cooldown on repairing; have a good fire extinguishing power but low fire immunity time, and so forth. Playing engineer is rather hard, unless the Captain gives you good builds and orders for keeping your ship alive.Even though a crew can hold on well enough without an engineer by being able to fix their ship, they won't last long enough since it will distract the entire crew to fixing the ship.There is also a variety of different maps. There are big maps and medium maps. Big ones are only open to non-novice difficulty. The environment is also quite dangerous in these maps. There are sand storms and snow storms that will do bad things like damaging your ship when in it.Finally, there is customization. In order to not have your ships and characters look all the same you can modify their colors, skins, hats, clothes, ship's logo, ships colors, etc, etc. You unlock some while you can also buy the rest from the in-game store. Note, these do NOT give any perks or advantages for your team, only the cool looks.All in all, this game highly relies on crew communication and strategy of your captains.I don't think we would of ever seen a game like this, it makes communication the first priority in any crew.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												I was skeptical about this game after playing the old Unreal engine mod, but we've come a long way since then. It's easy to get your feet wet and enjoy yourself in a low-stress role with a mostly friendly community. But underneath lies a complex engine with an unexpectedly high skill ceiling involving trajectories, guns & ammo combinations, maneuvering, repair strategies, and coordination with your teammates over voice chat. It's easy to let your imagination run wild with all the other fun possibilities you'd like to see plugged into this framework. I'd love to see boarding parties, or massive juggernauts with huge crews, or a campaign mode. Typically when a player is analyzing a game and saying to themselves "I wish it had ...", it's a bad sign. But in this case it really isn't, because the foundation they've laid is already a boat load of fun.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
Product received for free
												Overall positive but I'll look at both sides.What does GoI Online do right?Great team mechanics - if you're looking for a LAN party game, something to play with a small group of friends online or if you just want to enjoy a team game where you have to work and communicate with other players, it's a perfect game for you. You seriously cannot win in this game without co-ordination between crew members, so it's perfect for that sort of dynamic.Relatively good graphics - the textures are nothing special in GoI, but a lot of the video effects used can give a great atmosphere. Not only that, but the entire design of the game is fantastic. Every ship and map has its own unique look and feel.Awesome sound design - There isn't a lot of music in the game, but where it does feature, it's great. Sound effects are also awesome. When battles get intense, you feel it, especially when you have good headphones.Great concept - the actual idea of GoI is awesome and unique, and something I'm surprised more companies and developers haven't tried to capitalise on. More games like it are springing up, but GoI is still a very unique and exclusive experience. There isn't a game quite like this anywhere elseNow, the downsides.Low population - probably GoI's most prominent flaw is its low player count. There simply aren't a lot of people playing this game compared to when it was first released, and that's especially bad when you've got a multiplayer game where players are far more valuable than AI. I've experienced instances where one lobby has left and disbanded, only for all of the same players to form up in a different lobby since nobody else is online. You'll see this happen a lot and it can be monotonous.Long grind - you do get levels, achievements and collectibles in this game, and gaining all of them can be brutal and long. Your levels are divided between three different classes, so you have to level all three to stay competitive, meaning you can't just focus one class and hope for the best. You will spend a lot of time in this game putting effort in and still getting little as a result other than the actual gameplay experience.Lack of depth - GoI has a solid framework, but behind that, there isn't that much. Little to no lore, no expansion on regions or ships, and also a very basic meta. Some guns counter some stuff, others counter other stuff. It's as simple as that 90% of the time. No combinations or workarounds like in other games like this. Get ready to pick a style and keep it, chances are everyone else is playing the same way. This is also an issue when you consider the price of this game. I was fortunate enough to receive this game as a gift, but I have friends who refuse to buy the game simply because some things (lore, story, gameplay depth) aren't there, and don't justify the price tag for them.Overall, GoI is a fantastic game, but it is lacking in features which I wish the developers would work on. And honestly, considering the lack of a large playerbase and the lack of effort being put towards the game by the devs, I wouldn't be surprised if this game goes F2P in the near future. Personally, I think it should, this game needs an influx of new players badly. Still, a fun game, and it definitely has features you may be looking for.7/10

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												This is exclusively online and is definitely different than most games. You go on a flying ship with a crew of four. One drives the vessel and the other three shoots at other ships and repair yours. You’re two ships on each team (two teams). There is different objectives but the gameplay differ very slightly. It’s team deathmatch, king of the hill and hunter hunted. All of them is you and your crew-members keeping your fly-ship afloat and the enemies not so much.  The most fun is when you feel a good sync between crew members. That is why I recommend that you find three other friends to play with. I only played with one friend and two strangers and that does bring down the gameplay a lot for me. It’s vital that you have a oral way to bring information. Time and timing is of, as all 90:s commercials would say, EXTREME importance in this game (you should read out extreme in a cool voice). I do recommend the game but will warn you that it’s not so much wild action. The ships are slightly clumsy and a lot of gameplay is repairing rather than blasting. With friends this game is almost a must buy. Without friends you might want to double check your alternatives. PS: Works on LINUX!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I have played Guns of Icarus for 16 hours at the time of writing, but I know all that I need to to write this review, and hopefully help any new players thinking of getting the game themselves. First and last, there is an almost necessary yet unspoken social contract in guns of Icarus which you are almost required to follow.First: you must make an effort to learn the game. If you think that Guns can be played like any lone-wolf solo game, you will be ostracized until you get serious. Observe what others do, and follow suit until you get it, so that you drag others down as little as possible. There's a lot you won't get at first.Second: the captain can be contested, but follow his orders anyways. Captains can be (and often are) wrong, but they usually know the most about game flow. Respect their decisions, but don't be afraid to say that they are incorrect if you have a good reason.Third: know the crew before you try and captain. If you haven't played gunner or engineer for at least three rounds each, don't bother being a captain. You probably don't know enough to be good at it yet, that's just a fact.Fourth: your class roles are important, but not set in stone. Gunners have an extra repair tool, and engineers have an extra ammo type for a reason. Just beacuse you are one class doesn't mean you can't play as another (just that you probably shouldn't).Fifth and final: be a sportsman. Respect your enemies, and respect your allies. If you aren't willing to do your best, don't bother. It really shows when someone doesn't care, and everyone can see it.If you can do all those things, Guns will gladly let you into the ranks of its own. The pros will be able to help you and answer your questions, and in a few short hours of these you'll be pretty good too. Guns is daunting at first, but it's simple once you get it. Keep trying your best, and you'll be great at it in almost no time.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												The concept of this game is great. You fly around and have airship dogfights, and you can use all your sailing terminology like you know what it all means!The tutorial went thru pretty quick, so I'd recommend taking the time to play them twice and review the controls.Matchmaking never takes more than a few minutes to find a match, and empty crew slots are filled with AI. From what I've seen, AI can be lacking and you'll wish you want a real player. Until you get matched with someone who doesn't know what's going on... then you'll want your AI back. If someone leaves, AI take their place which is a huge plus in these kind of games as you aren't left shorthanded.There is a bit of a learning curve, but leveling is slow which gives you the time to get on page with everything. Once you reach level 8 you are no longer restricted to novice matches.I have not yet reached level 8, so I have limited customization of ships and characters. But it seems you can modify anything from your ship guns down to your character's voice.Playing solo is not a hinderance, you can ingame text and voice chat to your crew, team, or captains. But if you have a group of friends who are looking for a game to play.. Look No Further!9.5/10

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Had this game for a while but never bothered actually playing an online game until just recently. That said, I'm not sure how this game used to fare back then but it seems to have come a long way. I would go as far as saying it's one of the better games that requires some actual team effort. With your crew depending on an able Captain and or Pilot to steer them in the right direction and vice versa to keep the ship flying and fight back whilst under enemy fire.Some may say the different roles by themselves lack a bit of depth but I think their straightforward playstyle makes it more approachable to newcomers, and I'm doubtful if making it any more complicated would better the game. Furthermore difficulty comes with the ship you'll be flying on which depends on your crew Captain's choice and is open to customization at his/her will as they can be armed with different weapons to specialize in long and/or short range, and each ship has different stats and difficulty in management.As with many games based on teamwork, voice communication is a plus but like I said; because of how direct the roles are, a crew with a bit of commons sense would fare just fine without or by using the in-game commands / text messaging. On contrary to popular belief, the AI isn't as bad as one would think.. people write them off so easily because they are unaware of the existence of orders which if given properly and timely, make the AI a formidable crew not to take lightly. This is however my experience and may be subject to change on higher levels / advanced ships though I highly doubt it unless there's some kind of pathfinding issues.The game has been on sale many times before and packs quite some value at that because in it's current state I do think it's worth the normal pricetag. If you like being part of a crew on an air ship and conquer the skies alongside others in a setting a la steampunk this game is as close as you can get. The feeling of seeing your ship and or crew unleashing hell on your foes and landing those hits is exhilarating to say the least.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												Guns of Icarus Review (Level 18, 68h) :+ Pros- Unique game in its genre. Play as a crew in a steampunk ship ! Be either the captain, the gunner, or one of the two engineers. - Graphics are very good, although a bit dated. The art direction is magnificient, it's a pleasure to fly through the different environment.- Combat is really well done, although you need to get some knowledge on how it works to fully understands it. Spend time to experiment etc.- Usually good community.- Good price for what it is- A freaking lot of achievements for those who want to grab them all !- The cash shop is purely cosmetical, and it allows to customise your character (a lot) and your ship (very little).- Negatives-You need friends and a voice communication to get a good experience. Playing alone or without voice com will make you bored, frustrated and angry.- Not much content. 5 ships, a good variety of weapons, but you're quickly going to get through everything. However mastering them takes skill and time, and of course a good crew.- PVP only so far, so brace yourself. Alliance DLC is coming soon though with PVE and more content.- Small but dedicated playerbase. You have to learn quickly or you'll get stomped by veterans.Overall : 9/10 with a full 4 player crew,  5/10 without. The game offers an unique and incredibly fun experience if you can get 3 of your friends on it. If not, then you'll quickly lose interest in it, as you can not put advanced strategies and likely get stomped in loop. The Alliance DLC might be a life changer though, as a PVE experience could bring a lot of new players and be quite enjoyable even withotu a full crew on vocals. We'll see !Final verdict : Excellent game, for casuals or pros alike, provided you have 3 or more friends with you.
