content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												I wouldn't consider this game an action oriented game by any means, it's a strategy game. Everyone starts off with the same equipment, but you can customize your ship or your character to match your crew(always work in a 4 man group). There is no such thing as going lone wolf in this game. Each ship has 4 people on it, one controls it/gives orders,  and the rest maintain the ship and shoot other ships, which can be good or bad thing depending on your teammates/captain. There are three roles you get on this game: Engineer- Your main focus is repair, you are what keeps the ship going. Most of this play style is based on time management and focus; the difficulty of this class is based on the ship you're on. Sometimes you'll have an easy time maintaining the ship  and shooting guns when you have the chance, othertimes your focus will fully be on repairs. Since engineers are the ones who get around the ship the most, it's also handy to keep an eye out for enemy ships coming from the captain's blindspotsGunner- uses the guns, but mostly manages the rounds in that gun.The rounds you pick before the match begins are important, they decide the effect the gun has on your gun/enemy ship. Sometimes with this class you might need to make an emergency repair, but most of the time you're maintaining your gun and firing on the enemy ship. Each gun also affects different parts of the enemy ship in different ways, so play around until you understand what gun works best on what you're aiming at.Captain- As a captain, you organize your ship and your crew before the match begins, and then pilot the ship in game. You're the person in charge on your ship, and you work together with the other captain to decide how to attack or defend against the enemy ship. Communication as a captain is very important, along with strategy and picking your fights. A good knowledge of how the guns work and how your ship gets repaired can help in deciding what you can do with that ship.I would recommend this game if you like strategy and teamwork over brute force. The community is a close knit one where everyone knows everyone else practically, and is very open to helping new players along, so feel free to ask questions to higher level players or hop on ships and ask what they want you to bring/do. Just be patient, and have fun with it.

Looking for co-op?Guns of Icarus is a unique game with an interesting concept. Our group purchased a 4-pack on sale and got a good night of gaming out of it. There is no "campaign" or story versus the AI. You'll be playing as a team - competitively against other teams. The game queue times aren't always short, but the individual matches last long enough to make the wait worthwhile. Even the least competitive players in our group of 4 were able to have fun with it. I would still wait for a sale before purchasing it though.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Guns of Icarus Online... sounds promising, doesn't it? And it pretty much is VERY promising. I mean, I could probably go on and on about how good this game is and how I just adore it, even though I didn't really play that much (seeing as some people have 1k+ hours on this and I have a mere 27+). I'll try to make it as brief of a review as I can but don't blame me if it ends up pretty long (because there's a number of things I wish to describe).My first thought about this game was 'Oh my, a steampunk game about airships! Now that's a must have!'. I should probably tell you know that I'm a BIG steampunk fan. But back to the topic at hand: when I bought Guns of Icarus Online and actually got into a real game I was stunned. And no it wasn't because it was bad. Two words: airship battles. And not the kind you would expect from a regular multiplayer deathmatch oriented game where you fly a ship and pew pew everything in sight. Instead you get a team effort game. You and three other people are the whole crew of an airship (and you have about seven to choose from). You man the guns, keep the blasted thing alive and shoot other airships. Each member of your glorious crew is of one of the following professions: captain (responsible for flying the ship), engineer (repairs and rebuilds the ship parts) or gunner (your pew pew man). Of course, there some multi-classing aspects and everyone can attend to other jobs (only not so well).Doesn't sound impressive? Well then, let me assure you that those combats are gloriously dynamic. You run around whacking things with a rubber mallet, shoot things or manoeuvre through the skies, hoping you don't get sandwiched by two Galleons and you can actually FEEL that you're a part of the crew. And it's not that you "carry" people to victory. It's completely about the effort of everyone on the ship. I don't know about others but those kind of feels really get to me.And speaking of airships, they are designed so very well. They have this steampunk touch I so love about them. And not only that they look really well they also come in a decent variety. On one side of the list you have a big, slow airship packed with tons of heavy weaponry. On the other there's a fast, mobile ship with no heavy guns (though has an annoying tendency to burn you all the time). Maybe something in between? Though there's only seven ships, I'm sure most people will find something that suits them (my two personal favourites are the Spire and the Mobula). The only downside I can see here is that some of the ships are the engineer's worst nightmares (ironic that my favourites are those nightmares... and I play the engineer).Now let's speed this review up a bit. The graphics are nice. I really like the particles and how the ships look. So that's a plus. And the music is really good. The voice chat is pretty handy and helps a lot. Alas, the game has a few flaws. The first one is that it tends to lag from time to time for no big reason (which isn't really that frustrating... I, for one, don't really mind) so you end up falling off through the floor of your ship or see a teleporting enemy, and the part you were so eagerly smashing with your mallet isn't very responsive. The second one that comes into my minds is that... it's hard to find games and crew. Don't get me wrong, there's quite a lot of people playing this game but it just doesn't seem enough. Mornings and early afternoons are simply underpopulated (I know, people have lives... but what are the odds?). I know it's not really a technical flaw, but it kind of gets me down. And lastly I... don't really have any major flaws to report.And I must say that the developers are fantastic. So is the community. I don't think I've ever seen such a friendly community in any online game.So... that was a tad longer than I intended it to be. No matter. To sum things up: Guns of Icarus Online is a very good online game. It's a perfect buy for any steampunk fan out there who would like to actually participate in an airship battle and feel like a real sky pirate (or maybe not really a pirate but you get the point). And when you get friends to man your ship? Now that's the best thing you can do with your free time. I recommend this game to everyone, not only to those who like steampunk. In general, this is a pretty darn good multiplayer team effort game. So go buy it. We need more pilots, gunners and engineers.

												Ths game was such a good surprise! I started playing this game with friends not really knowing what to expect, and it turned out to be something like the best co-op game we've played!Basically, 4 players on a flying ship: 1 pilot, the 3 others are gunners or mechanics. This can be problematic if you play with randomly selected people on the internet, because communication on online game doesn't always work perfectly!

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Guns of Icarus Online is the best airship combat game out there, in my opinion. It really is a great game. At any given time there are hundreds of people playing the game, and for such a cheap and small title, that's a rather large community of gamers.Anywhere from 1 on 1 to 3 on 3 airships can battle eachother. There are 4 crew members per airship, up to a total of 24 people in any given game at a time. And better yet, if there aren't enough people, there is AI that will fill in the slots.So, what's so fun about this game? A bunch of different airships to pilot? A multitude of turrets to man and rain destruction down upon your enemies? Constant havoc being wreaked upon your ship that you need to fix? How about all of the above! With 3 different classes, all capable of performing every single airship task, however each with their own unique sets of equipment and buffs, the Gunner, the Pilot, and the Engineer. This game is a real blast.Give it a try, and don't knock it until you do. Firefights in the sky among floating balloon-boats. Yeah.

As the crew, you have to communicate with the Captian to be able to do what you must, and as Captain you must listen to your crew as well as pilot the ship independently.  And for $11.99, it is a very good game.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Probably one the best games that I have ever played. And I'm not putting that lightly.Pros:+ Decent graphics+ Cool idea+ Good class balance+ No pay to win (only cosmetics)+ Loads of teamwork involved+ Lots of awesome artwork/designs for ships and clothing+ Matchmaking is good+ Not too bad of a price+ Gets really intense and can leave you feeling like you actually were there, fighting alongside your friends+ Tutorial is easy and explanatory+ Tons and tons and tons of customization. Literally anything you could think ofCons:- Not well optimised. With my mid-high end custom-built desktop, I run at a solid 60fps until I get into a fight with explosions of any kind, which can sometimes drop my frames to a mere 20-30fps- Not all the ships are perfectly balanced. There aren't any ships that are overpowered, though some of the ships are never used simply because they aren't as balanced as the others- Leveling up doesn't have that many rewards- Not a lot of maps, though you rarely notice your surroundings unless you're a pilot or there's no fighting going onOther Ideas:~ If you are playing with a group of 4 friends, this game is, well, simply awesome. However, if you find yourself with any less than 4 of your friends, you can sometimes end up with a newbie crewmate~ The game doesn't REQUIRE a microphone, though it seems nearly pointless without one. Without the ability to communicate with your crew/party with live voice chat, trying to say things like "THE BALLOON IS ON FIRE" can only be said with the (somewhat hard to navigate) built-in voice chat (think TF2 voice commands)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												I wouldn't consider this game an action oriented game by any means, it's a strategy game. Everyone starts off with the same equipment, but you can customize your ship or your character to match your crew(always work in a 4 man group). There is no such thing as going lone wolf in this game. Each ship has 4 people on it, one controls it/gives orders,  and the rest maintain the ship and shoot other ships, which can be good or bad thing depending on your teammates/captain. There are three roles you get on this game: Engineer- Your main focus is repair, you are what keeps the ship going. Most of this play style is based on time management and focus; the difficulty of this class is based on the ship you're on. Sometimes you'll have an easy time maintaining the ship  and shooting guns when you have the chance, othertimes your focus will fully be on repairs. Since engineers are the ones who get around the ship the most, it's also handy to keep an eye out for enemy ships coming from the captain's blindspotsGunner- uses the guns, but mostly manages the rounds in that gun.The rounds you pick before the match begins are important, they decide the effect the gun has on your gun/enemy ship. Sometimes with this class you might need to make an emergency repair, but most of the time you're maintaining your gun and firing on the enemy ship. Each gun also affects different parts of the enemy ship in different ways, so play around until you understand what gun works best on what you're aiming at.Captain- As a captain, you organize your ship and your crew before the match begins, and then pilot the ship in game. You're the person in charge on your ship, and you work together with the other captain to decide how to attack or defend against the enemy ship. Communication as a captain is very important, along with strategy and picking your fights. A good knowledge of how the guns work and how your ship gets repaired can help in deciding what you can do with that ship.I would recommend this game if you like strategy and teamwork over brute force. The community is a close knit one where everyone knows everyone else practically, and is very open to helping new players along, so feel free to ask questions to higher level players or hop on ships and ask what they want you to bring/do. Just be patient, and have fun with it.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Got myself a mohawk, a leather jacket and an airship... Awesome. This game has proven to be a love-hate relationship, because it has so much potential to be something more, it annoys me that the game hasn't advanced beyond it's emcumbered means of bashing a hammer to repair stuff and manning the same old usual weaponry to shoot other ships. Don't get me wrong, it's amazing in it's own right and I'm continuing to spend many hours playing it to date, but it has potential to be even better in my eyes; I know for one that being able to physically invade another airship "pirate style" would be amazing and give a far more entertaining contrast to the monotomy of what soon becomes reptitive tasks in the game. If you enjoy team-work (this is a must) and quite enjoy naval warfare (but you're flying!) then this game is pretty awesome and even if you don't enjoy those things, but mindlessly enjoy bashing components on the airship and shooting steam-punk weaponry, then you'll enjoy this game anyway. Like I said however, it can become somewhat boring fast, so be sure to have a dapper crew to keep you entertained.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												TL;DR at bottomOverall: 8/10Game is pretty fun, worth picking up on sale, or if you have some extra money.Gameplay: 10/10Hectic team based airship battles, that you get to experience as a crewman on the ships. It's so badass.Optimization: 6/10I'm running a decently nice computer and I occasionally get FPS drops on high graphics.Variety: 7/10There's only 7(I think) ships and 4 heavy guns. There are about 20 light guns, but I'd like to see more heavy guns and more ships.Visuals: 9/10On high graphics, the game looks really nice. I am never distracted by low res textures or ugly looking ships. Everything looks like it belongs.Music: 10/10The soundtrack startled me at first. I didn't expect this game to have music that was actually amazing. For a game with 0 focus on music, it's amazing. The sounds are perfect during combat, the music compliments without overwhelming. Very nice.Replayability: 10/10Battles are never the same, there are 466 achievements to work on, you can always get better at your class, you can learn another class. There are nearly infinite things to do in this game.Something Good:I've made some good friendships in this game. The community is really great, everyone tries to work together, and trolls are hard to find. Once you get out of the lower levels, you are hardly ever going to find anyone trolling, because the amount you have to commit to get to the higher levels means that no one is going to level a character just to troll.Something bad: If you want this game to be fun, you need a group of three other people to play with. You can find them in Guns of Icarus, get IRL friends, whatever, but you need a full party for this game to remain fun for long. If you don't, it will rapidly become dull, you'll lose frequently. Overall, it'll suck.Overview:Basically, you fly around in an airship, blowing other ships out of the sky. It's pretty fun. You can specialize by picking one of three classes, gunner, engineer, or pilot. Each has their strengths and something they are good at. Pilots have the ability to trade the health of the ship for speed or turning power. Engineers have the ability to repair parts, rebuild parts, or buff parts. Gunners can take three types of ammo into the match, giving them the ability to react to different situations. A well played ship is a thing of beauty. Pilot sails you in, gunner unloads their weapon into the enemy ship, the engineer is buffing all of the parts and healing the ship when it takes damage. It's a wonderful feeling. Dog fights can last seconds or minutes, depending on the skill of the crews.TL;DR: At best, the game is hectic, skill based, and stupidly fun. When your ship finally clicks and works properly, when you're calling out orders in the thick of battle, when you finally destroy the ship you're fighting, the feeling is amazing. If you don't have a group of friends to play with, this probably won't happen often, and you'll lose interest and end up hating it. 8/10

												Ths game was such a good surprise! I started playing this game with friends not really knowing what to expect, and it turned out to be something like the best co-op game we've played!Basically, 4 players on a flying ship: 1 pilot, the 3 others are gunners or mechanics. You must destroy enemy ships, whilst taking the least damage possible, or you'll explode yourself (this is why mechanics are important).There's a general steampunk look to the game that is quite well done.As I said, cooperation is really important, and when I was playing with friends, we really did have the feeling that we were winning - or loosing - as a team. This can be problematic if you play with randomly selected people on the internet, because communication on online game doesn't always work perfectly!

content:
Posted: January 14, 2013
												Very fun and engrossing action/strategy.  Airship battles set in a steampunk atmosphere.  Everything relies on your team working together which is made up of specialized members, ie unique classes/equipment loadouts which can be customized.  There is absolutely no "rambo'ing" in the game.  There are no individual stats displayed at the end of each round, although they are tracked so you can review them yourself, and do contribute to your character leveling up.  Leveling your character confers no in-game bonus, but does serve as an indicator of how much experience you have playing the game.  However, a team of veterans who do not pull together with their ship can easily be out-maneuvered and overpowered by a team of noobs who are actually working together, albeit even without a great understanding of how the game works.  This is accomplished by built in voice support which automatically moves you to channels for the game lobby and your ship, once the action starts.  The captains of the ships can also use a separate channel to plan strategy amongst themselves before handing out orders to their crew.  That's what makes it such an interesting dynamic.  The ships are competing, not the individuals.  The crews are completing, not the individuals that make them up.  It is also nice to play a game where the devs and mods play often and are available for questions.  They've even added a couple new maps since I started playing a few weeks ago.

There's a bit of a learning curve but generally the community is willing to help you out and show you around a ship. content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												10/10Where to start. To get my "opinion" out of the way, this is the greatest game I have ever played. Now that that is settled, to the game itself.I'm sure that you've read various other reviews telling you that the game is very team oriented. I cannot stress this enough, and let me tell you why. Since this is an FPS game, there is NO 3rd PERSON MODE. Not even as the pilot. This forces the crew members to cooperate with eachother in a way that I have never experienced before, and it is something to behold. Communication and cooperation are key, whether the balloon and engines need repair, the gunner is slightly out of range, a sandstorm is approaching from behind, or an enemy ship is right above you, everyone has to be ready to communicate."But thats impossible! No gaming community is cooperative, or friendly, enough to offer that kind of experience." Let me tell you that again and again the community that composes this game is not only the most friendly, but the most helpful that I have ever encountered. As a newcomer I knew this game like the back of my hand in no time, thanks to the help of some random players I met in game lobbies. The lobbies are full of fun times and cool people from all over, and everyone wants everyone to have a good game experience.Last, but cetainly not least, the gameplay. Flying these ginormous clunky ships is something you won't find anywhere else. It is a unique experience that requires a bit of skill and teamwork, but theres something so incredibly addicting and charming about it that just makes you want more. Your ship is stacked with customizable guns for different purposes, long range, medium range, short range, armor piercing, balloon damage, explosive damage, and tons more. There is always something to ready for, parts to repair and buff, guns to extiguish and load with the appropriate ammo, and enemies and hazards to be spotted. There are also environmental hazards, such as terrain to doge, weave, and hide around and sandstorms that sneak out out of nowhere.To put the gameplay in perspective, think of this: Your ship is charging out of a cloud at the unprotected side of an enemy ship. Gunners man the front guns and open fire while the captain rushes in for a ram. Your ship hits theirs and glances off to the right, while their ship spins around and is facing your right side. The situation is now a scramble, gunners running to the right side guns of the ship and trying not to fall off in the process, mechanic repairing damage to the hull from the ram, and the captain trying to get the ship out of the enemy's range of fire. The enemy ship is now facing guns forward at yours and starts pounding away with a mortars and a flamethrower, disabling your side guns and deflating your balloon. Your ship is slowly falling, the captain has decided to retreat and the whole crew is focused of keeping the hull in repair and the balloon inflated. Despite the crew's efforts, the hull's armor is down and the ship is now taking direct damage. Lucky for you, your ally ship bursts from the cloud in front of you and totally saves the day, finishig off the enemy and giving you time to repair. This is just a little taste of the exitement and thrill of this game.When I found this game, it was because I was looking for a cool steampunk game to play. This game has all the steampunk charm you could hope for, in the ships, in the setting, and in the customizable characters. As a steampunk fan, I can honestly say that this game completey satisfies my need for steampunk stuff. I love this game, I love this community, and I highly reccomend this game to anyone who wants to experience something new.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Guns of Icarus Online lets you slip into an intense battle on airships with explosions, chaos and drama. In a team of four, your goal is to wreck the enemie's ships while trying to stay above ground. The right ship with the fitting set of guns with a working crew is essential for victory.You can choose between three roles:♦Pilots are steering the ship and use a set of items to help them navigate. A very stressful role, because it's up to the pilot if the ship should engage the enemy, stay aside to the team or flee from battle. Therefor the pilot is mostly the captain who leads the crew and keeps them working as a unit. If you like to be a leader, this is your position!♦Engineers can rarely sit down and calmly drink a beer, as their job is to keep the ship together. With their set of tools they can rebuild, repair and even buff compoments of the ship. Whenever there's fire to extinguish, the engineer's here to save your head. Be the one who everyone should be thankful to that they are still alive!♦Gunners take their set of different ammunitions to the guns and choose the right kind to deal the most possible damage. Gunning is not to be underestimated because it does take skill to let a bullet hit the target when the pilot's driving like a drunken sailor. You are the one to burn enemies down with the flamethrower or rip their balloon into pieces with the canon!Communication is crucial in Guns of Icarus Online. For instance: The captain tells the gunner to man certain guns because he is about to position the ship in a certain way and engineers should focus on the engines because the captain burns them down with kerosine to gain speed. A microphone and the willing to talk are never wrong, but if you don't have one of the two things, you can use macros to share information, which is on my experiences enough. Text is also possible, but should be used carefully because it is likely that suddenly an enemy's firing at you while you are slamming keys on your keyboard.Because this game is filled with stressful situations and wrong decisions it's possible that crewmembers get frustrated and start to talk in a sharp way, but mostly the community keeps a cool head and tell you in a calm way what should be done and what should be avoided. If you are new in this game, there are novice gamelobbies where you play with people with about the same experience and most people are friendly enough to explain certain elements and rules. Ragequitters are marked with a low 'Match Completition Rate" and when a crewmember does leave the game, another player replaces the position pretty soon. In my whole playtime I 'only' had one griefer who surrendered immediately on the first death and blocked the gameplay instead of leaving the game, and in such cases you can report player for their behaviour fast and easy after the match.Different types of ships, a good selection of weapons and interesting maps are what makes this game enjoyable, but what's truly great is that every match is different. Every captain has their own strategy, situations change from a promised defeat to a glorious victory and there are hardly any boring pauses after the start of a match. It is incredible fun when you play this game with three other friends together and work out plans and maneuvers.Guns of Icarus Online is simply great!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												I would recommend this game to anyone who has three friends to play with. The community in this game is one of the best. It isnt tainted like League of Legends. It is a very respectible community and even if they start yelling at you, it's mostly because they are trying to help you make a better player. They have tought me a lot on how the game mechanics work and which loadout is best suited for each ship. The developers will occasionally play with you and they are one of the nicest developers you can meet. One thing you will expect is that this game is a waiting simulator. You will consistly wait for people to join in as most people will look for active games. Some of the players will quit on you when your ship gets blown up on the first kill or before they loose which really makes me mad. Why bother quiting in the end when you just played a whole round?The gameplay is awesome for what it is. You get to choose between three classes: Captain, Engineer, and Gunner. The Captain is what the name states. You are in control of airships telling your crewmates what to do. You can customize your characters and ships to what you want. Examples is the color, guns, emblems, and interior. For the characters: head, face, types of scars, clothing, color of skin, hair, and color of clothing but back to the classes. The Engineer is your repair, fire control, and buff guy. The Gunner is your guns expert. The crewmates consist of four players including yourself so you can have a crew full of Engineers and a Captain. The combat is very strategic even in Deathmatch. Why do I say that? Well each ship has its own roll. Your ship can be designed for CQB but the ship your going against is good for long range and you can get demolished because of that. Teamwork and communication with your crew and teammates is a must to conquer this game. Overall, I give this game an 8/10. It is a game that you have to give it a try. I saw on Facebook that the PS4 and PC plays can now play together when they release it which is a huge plus now that it will add more players to the game. Give it a try and you will not disappoiant. See you all on in the sky. Round of drinks on me tonight at the pub lads.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Guns of Icarus Online is a multiplayer team-based shooter/flight sim/makeshift percussion instrument simulator sequel to the original Guns of Icarus by Muse games. All set in a quirky alternate history where World War I apparently started early and dragged out until humanity was left in a post-apocalyptic state where airships are the way to go because Mad Max makes land travel too lethal.You are one of three classes, pilot (only one per-ship, directs the ship), engineer (repairs stuff), and gunner (controls the gun mounts) in a group of four (guess which class gets doubled up?) and while each class can man the guns, pilot the ship, and even do some repairs, the classes have customizable loadouts in different categories. Your class gets four tools in their chosen category and only one tool in any other. You and the rest of your crew must function as a tight knit, well-coordinated unit as pilots must keep the ship positioned to fire on enemies, gunners must have an aim worth squat, and engineers need to stay on top of incoming damage to different parts of the ship. Thankfully, unlike the original Guns of Icarus, you no longer have to worry about cargo, just your teammates (including those on other, friendly ships) being subpar to the team members on the opposite team.What ensues is a game requiring multi-person coordination, open communication, a careful system of checks and balances in terms of equipment loadout, ship class, and armaments in perhaps a great game of teamwork and strategy I myself have never experienced before. Some things you'll need to full enjoy this game will easily be friends to form a crew with (and expendable when the inevitable lost match causes a falling out) or patience, willingness, and possible divine favor to endure the randomized matchmaking, and lastly a good quality mic for communicating with your team or chewing out the other engineer who keeps repairing something you're already fixing when something else needs him more.But by no means let these words discourage you, indeed, sometimes the frustration can be part of the fun and makes the times when you and your team hit the zone or you end up with just good teammates a zen-like experience of being awesome as the crew of the Enterprise, deftly taking down superior forces of Klingon warships except with more cogs and petrol fumes.If PVP isn't your thing, the developers have been working on a PvE adventure mode for some time now and progress is apparently steady. Adventure mode will include not just AI controlled enemies, but also towns which you can visit with your avatar character to show off those fancy duds you bought in the cash store, role play your way through your lack of actual skills related to your class, or simply argue your ship is better than everyone elses/complain how broken flamethrowers are.Oh, did I mention you can not just customize your avatar but also your ship to an extent aesthetically? Well you can, it costs real money but distinguishing yourself is always nice.Perhaps the current downside is that mechanical options are limited, There's maybe eight different tools to select from for each class, only so many ships, and only so many ways you can load them up in terms of weapons. Things get more restrictive when it comes to the metagame as while the engineers are always important, you end up doing a lot less exciting things and can spend whole matches staring at ship components and smashing them with a tool for repairs or putting out fires because the one gunner and one pilot slot were taken by someone else (and begrudgingly, probably more deserving of those slots than you).All in all, I highly recommend this game to people, if only to support indie development, and to promote strategic, teamwork dependent multiplayer games. Nevermind hope for future growth and perhaps a broader meta.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												I should begin by saying that a fully fledged PvE mode is in the works, though there is no ETA of when it will be done. This game is a bit of something most people always wanted to have, but never did. If you played the final fantasy games as a kid, like I did, then you probably wondered what a full on battle with your airship would be like.Guns of Icarus neatly fulfills that by combining slick killer airships, steampunk glory, and the dear old dreams of flight. It's you and three other players, who must steer the airship itself, fire the weapons to take down the enemy, and keep the ship repaired at all times.Pilot, gunner, and engineer - not a toughie to figure out who does what. While it's worth noting that any role can do anything, pilots gets more items to enhance the performance of the ship itself (at the expense of slowly damaging the systems), gunners get more ammo types, and engineers have more tools to fix the ship.Decking out your ship is where the real depth lies. There are a lot of weapons at this stage of the game, and knowing what to have when, and at what place of the ship, and with what ammo, is the key to victory. You could be a sniping minelayer, a harpoon'ing flamerboat, or a pure on rocket speedster. There's a lot of combinations, and you will still be learning new ones hundreds of games later. The ships are as varied as the weapons, offering multiple roles per ship depending on what guns and ammo you use. Playing into all of this are the items the pilot is using, be it moonshine to make the engines go faster, kerosense to make the balloon better, or phoenix claw to turn faster - it all comes down to making up for the various ships inate weaknesses. But, as previously mentioned, that comes at the cost of constantly damaging the affected sub-systems, so pilots needs to take care of that.See, damage to systems makes them less effective - an engine that's barely alive won't perform anywhere near a full repaired one, and the same goes for everything else. It's all a matter of making priorities under fire, which makes every game intense but rewarding. And because every part of the ship has it's own health, a lot of tactical precision fire comes into play. Aim is important.The scenery is beautiful - I sometimes forget to do my job as an engineer because I get distracted by all the effects and cool visuals around me. No other game did that to me. It's that good to look at. It's not just scenery though, things like hiding in clouds is definetly a thing. The soundtrack is great, it's subtle but powerful, and often you won't notice it there - you will just suddenly realize how well it sets the mood, and you will quickly learn to fear the sound of hwacha rockets whistling through the air. But should the soundtrack dissapoint, your teammates can of course play their own over the mic - or whatever else they want to share. Guns of Icarus is extremely voice driven - you simply don't have the time to type under fire. Luckily, it's functional and simple. And better get used to it, because there will be a lot of banter going on in the ship. And that's what makes me adore this game so much, more than anything - people work very closely together to achive a common goal. That makes getting along so extremely important - if you don't have a good chemistry with your crew, then you simply won't do really well. Even in the pre-match lobbies, I often find myself heartily laughing at all the jokes, singing, stories, and general merry banter. It's sorta like a pre-match party!So yes, if you don't like social games, then this game is not optimized for you. But the community is incredibly inviting and nice!BUT, if you like airships, epic dogfights, flying in pretty landscapes, and just having a grand old gamer time with people from all over the world, duking it up high above the ground in all it's steampunk glory, and feeling the gratification of achieving success as a team, then this game is impossible to pass up. It's pretty much the only one of it's kind, and it's only getting better. The developer team constantly plays games with the players, so they're never out of touch or lack common insight. I hope to see you in the skies!PS: Two advices... Don't opt out of novice. Don't fly a galleon if you're not experienced.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												The only game in which you and three other players are literally stuck in the same boat.You can't jump in a match and do ... whatever. That doesn't fly here. This game at a base level requires some degree of coordination. But bring a modicum of sense and attention (and the ability to communicate either through text chat or microphone), and the community will more than happily bring you up to speed.Some say Guns of Icarus is best played by buying a 4-pack and grabbing three buddies to play with you. That may be, but I wouldn't know, as I almost exclusively joined random matches for my first 800 matches, and had a complete blast doing so.The game hasn't had any major updates lately, but what's there right now keeps me coming back again and again. Also, keep an eye out for the Alliance PvE DLC.Another issue would be a relatively low (but stable) population. It seems to settle around 200 players during a weekday evening a couple months after the most recent sale. Check SteamCharts for more info. However, as the player population is mostly concentrated in the Americas and Europe, there might only be some 40 players or so when you decide to give GoI a spin 4AM in the morning. But you'll still be able to find a match, thanks to the existence of AI crewman! That is, as long as you're fine with flying the ship while everyone else on your ship is an AI.Point is, don't worry about never getting into matches.On sale or not, Guns of Icarus is quite the steal if it turns out to be your cup of tea. I highly advise those on the fence to watch some Youtube Lets Plays of the game. They'll give you a pretty good idea of what you'll be flying into.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												If TLDR worries you... then, well, tldr ^^I am not an online gamer. Before I started playing Guns of Icarus Online (GoI), I went to the odd LAN-party, played with or against friends online, but the idea of playing with strangers was not something that I found appealing. On the other hand, I like airships and the whole steampunk shtick, and I had played the original Guns of Icarus (now Flight of the Icarus), with all its quirks and foibles. The multiplayer on the original game (now discontinued for good reason) was cute but horrible in so many ways, but that is another story – so that when I saw Guns of Icarus Online, I thought “why not?”. I was in the first wave of people to buy it in the first sale back in the day, and have not regretted it since.GoI is a game that relies on teamwork – sounds like old hat, and maybe it is, but this hat has steampunk goggles on it, and it fits perfectly. The fact is, neither levels nor experience points will buy you victory in GoI, because there are no abilities. A level 45 engineer has exactly the same tools and abilities at her disposal as a level 1 novice. Instead, you have to communicate with your teammates, listen to your captain, and respect and use your crew’s abilities. This can be incredibly rewarding, because when you win, it means YOU won – not a random assortment of stats that means you had the right abilities, no weird balancing effects and no pay-to-win annoyances. You won, all of you together. On the down side, this requires people who talk to each other. You don’t have to be a pro gamer to play GoI (Heaven knows I’m not), because while there are things that require experience and practice, like shooting certain guns or piloting certain ship types, there are many tasks that any new-comer can perform, and in which he (or she) can quickly learn the ropes and move on to the more complicated tricks, if that’s her/his thing. None of it will work, however, if you have a twit who thinks he is the self-appointed god of airshipping and considers co-ordination and teamwork to be the realm of lesser beings. Those people will not only fall on their faces, but ruin the match for their team-mates. In GoI, you work together or fail.That being said, there are only very few idiots out there. A lot has been said about the gaming community in Guns of Icarus, how it is better and friendlier than other communities – as I have said, I don’t have the comparisons to back that up, so all I can say is in the years I have played GoI, I have met about a dozen people who were true twerps, from ignorant engineers who thought they were a gunner to gunners who thought they were captain and kept shouting orders, to captains who thought they were Daedalus incarnate and knew everything. Yet I can name more than a dozen entire clans whose members are more than ready to accept and train with newbies, who are respectful, polite, and simply fun to be around. And that’s just the clans, there are hundreds of individual gamers in GoI who are nice, friendly and helpful, who all started out as newbies and have since become really good at the game. They are the majority, brass-plated hands down. I play most evenings, and about once a week, at most, we meet some guy who spams a lobby with stupid slogans, uses a racist airship name, or becomes hateful in some other way. I’m told this is relatively infrequent compared to other games, I wouldn’t know. At any rate those loud-mouths never stay for long, because as mentioned above, in order to play well you have to play together, and people like that don’t find anyone to play with, so the problem solves itself. So make no mistake. Guns of Icarus is not a game you come to for a quick feel-good experience in the “shoot stuff, loot its corpse, level up, shoot bigger stuff” kind of way. Everyone starts off a “noob”, and only your own experience with the game will improve your play. If you should be thinking of buying Guns of Icarus after reading this, you should probably consider getting a headset along with it. Be prepared to talk to others, be prepared to listen, and you will be fine. Odds are you will likely find friends within the first few days of gaming. The game can be played on a pro level, with the balancing and pros/cons weighted perfectly (if that’s the kind of thing you go for), but most of the time, it is simply getting to know your way around the different ships and guns, and knowing who does what. It’s not rocket science – it’s more airship art. Like in a martial art, you train, you train with others, you get better, you get more confident, and you earn the respect of others. And suddenly you realise you are no longer a novice, but a black-belt Pyramidion captain with a penchant for ramming speed, a crane-style Squid pilot who hovers just out of reach of the enemy’s guns, taking down their balloon and blowing them a kiss as they crash to the ground, or a Galleon commander who wades into battle to save the day with guns-a-blazing, his gunners dealing death and destruction with their expert broadsides. Or you find you prefer to be an engineer, turning the tide of battle with well-practiced routine, repairing at lightning speed while the enemies are still whacking their hulls in despair; or a gunner, shooting down the enemy components from a mile away, one by one, until all that is left are tears. But like in a “true” art, half of it is not about winning, but how you go about it – do you roleplay your pseudo-Victorian character in the lobby? Do you spend time putting together your perfect steampunk outfit and selecting the right colours and decals for your airships? Do you try to level, not because it gets you any tangible benefits, but because you want that damn outfit upgrade? Do you get to know your team-mates beyond who does what and who goes where? Odds are, you will – even though it does not mean a thing in the game results. And in the end, you will find you are part of a community, for better or worse. Personally, I have found Guns of Icarus never ceases to surprise me. As a level 45 captain with an experienced crew, you sometimes think nothing can take you down, and then a level 2 enemy captain with practically no experience comes and makes your match a living hell – and after the battle, you salute him, trade quips, and fly together. Maybe the silent gunner who never says a thing the entire match but simply follows orders turns out to be an Irishman with a wicked sense of humour once he’s warmed to you. Or you commence your in-flight speech with “Good evening gentlemen, welcome aboard…” only to check the roster and realise that your flight crew is in fact all-female. So if you like learning, enjoy being surprised, and are attracted to the idea of playing with and against others on a steampunk/dieselpunk airship, Guns of Icarus Online is for you. If you have time and money to spare, buy the four-in-one bundle on sale and distribute it amongst your friends, and you can start off together. And if you’re the kind of person who likes to troll, thinks he’s the best and plays to inflate his ego, come by too – maybe you will learn something during your stay. And even if you don’t, Muse can do with the money, and while it is not strictly necessary, blowing up trolls makes the game that much more fun for the rest of us ^^In any case, we look forward to seeing you in the skies!Phoenix42akaLord Scottworth of the HMS Discombobulator

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												This game provides a very unique experience that you won't find in other games. You can't quite describe the feeling - when you know the ship is going down, the captain isn't even at the steering wheel anymore but huddled in a corner wondering when it all went wrong, being razed by fire on both sides, all engines failing and balloon popped, you try and jump ship only to find yourself back on board... you'll have to try it yourself to understand. Gameplay is very balanced, nice variety of ships and guns and regularly updated for new content. The only criticisms I have are some lag/disconnection issues especially on foreign servers, and graphics aren't the greatest. The community is very friendly, and very competitive. Invest in a microphone, if you want to really get into it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												This is, in my opinion, one of those "one of a kind" games that i fall in love with. Where elese will you find a game where you can steer a steampunk stylised flying ship against others with actual human beings as your crew? This game got me right on since the very begining.I've been playing this game alot and what I like the most here is :-The maps which are perfectly accostumed for flying and manuvering ranging from more open ones to extremaly narrow ones like cities. They also feel like they belong to the world of the game which is important to me as not every game does it.-The co-operation which is crucial for this game make other players actully care for the communication and coordination  since this is one of those game that you absolutely have no chance playing solo and not listening to your teammates, especailly captain of the ship.-The theme is also a great attribute to this game. I think steampunk setting of the world fits perfectly here making all the ships, all the modules, all the guns and its animations and character costumes alot more enjoyable-The buisness model is very fair as the only things you can buy in shop are customisation items with pretty affordable prices I would say (if you can farm up some trading cards on steam you will even be able to buy a couple of those!).-Everything is unlocked from the very beginging, you do not need to through any mundune process of gradually gaining a new item once every couple of levels. Every ship, every gun, every tool or ammunition type is avail for all classes since the very beginging. While this might be kind of overwhelming for newcomers I can guarantee you that you will get a hang of it fairly early on.-The community here more often then so is in my opinion surprisingly helpful (yes you can find your standard ♥♥♥♥♥♥s who will be mad at anyone who screws up even a bit but they are in minority here). I've met alot of players who can call themsleves veterans and they were always willing to explain what should I do, how to act on a certains ships and set ups or what is the best combination of tools/ammunition I can take with me.This game for the majority of time was and still is alot of fun and competetiveness for me. If anything the only thing to put here and cons would probably be:-While being great the community is rather small for this game so I can't guarantee if this game will survive although it has been sustaining itself for quiet a long time and does a good job of it. Nevertheless I felt like it should have been signalised-Ignore this point if you do not care for achievements on steam. this game has a reallygood deal of achievements on steam making this a really long and grindy road to 100%. The other side of these here is that some of those will be especially hard to get as some of the achievements refer to new players giving you a recommendation and vice-versa. This would not actually be such a big problem if the community was bigger but as of now there is alot more old veteran players than the new ones.Overall I think the game is great and I strongly recommend others to try tis one out. Especially if you have a group of friends who would be willing to fly with you. The 4-pack deal is pretty great as you save up 20 euro that way making the game essentially 50% cheaper without a discount!I will say this if you like flying ships and raining down death on enemies you won't regret buying this game!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9
												Long story short, this game is an excellent game, and it's worth every penny.Details:STUFF I LIKE:- Gameplay in general. I like the idea of flying these airships, I like the matching system, using the weapons is good, flying the ship has great controls, engineering is pretty intuitive, it just all works really well- The teamwork specifically needs special mention. It's really great. It forces you to work with not only your crew, but your entire team. They made giving commands and orders really intuitive. Working together with your team and crew is awesome, and it makes you feel like an essential part of a team, which is something not a lot of games have. - The aesthetics are great. I just like the way it looks. I'm not a huge steampunk fan, but this game really does it well. - Character customization. This seems small, but being able to customize my character is a big deal to me, so I had to mention it. It's really good. STUFF I DON'T LIKE:- This is an issue that I guess can't really be avoided, but some of the players are hostile, and it makes them hard to work with. I know it shouldn't be a big deal, but it's really frustrating when someone won't cooperate on a game that relies heavily on cooperation. - Leveling up. This is a personal issue, but it seems like you level up WAY too slowly. It just seems like it takes an awfully long time to make any real progress. Although, that may be a by product of my next point- It takes a long time to play the game. A match usually won't start until it's mostly full, which is frustrating because filling a match can take a really long time when people are as impatient as they are. I don't know how the developers might fix this, but on the other hand, that's not really my job.- It can be a little confusing. I know this isn't a big deal, but it took me a really long time to figure out how to use all the engineering tools and how all the different types of ammo worked. I feel like these could have been explained by the game a little better, but maybe that's just me. Overall, in spite of its flaws, I think this game is worth it. It can be a little tough to get started, but once you get going, it really is a blast. If you've got some time to set aside for it, it's really a great game.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Fun 7/10^Very team dependant. One person slacking can ruin it. I have the most fun with real friends. Dont touch it much otherwise. Also, please have a mic.Graphics 6/10^Average. Not bad. Not amazing. They get the job done and will probably age nicely.Controls 10/10^ With keybindings it is hard to mess up on this. The game does what you tell it to.Replay Value6/10You can play this game forever. That would warrant a 10/10. HOWEVER, the game is not rewarding or rather, you play the same game over and over. Yes, different people make each match special.But imagine your favorite moba game. Everone has every character unlocked and there are only half as many characters. It is great fun for a while. But eventually, things get repetitive and dare I say boring.In Game Store10/10Not in your face.Purely cosmetic.Perfect.Balance5/10While the ships and weapons are balanced players are not. With a smaller community it can be difficult to fly with people of your level.That goes for within your own ship, and even against other players.If your engineer does not know what to repair, your gunner has bad aim, or your pilot turns your ship into a sitting target, it does not matter how good you are as an individual.Normally, this is where matchmaking, and some sort of player skill balance comes into play.But with a smaller community, this is not exactly the best choice to segregate players.Matchmaking5/10It can be difficult to get into a game.You can always find games.But, it can take a while.Game modes 4/10Plenty of game modes exist, and are played. I think this almost hurts the game though, because it puts players in a position of wanting to play a certain gamemode, and potentially nobody wants to play that mode. if 300 people are spread out over say 6 game modes(deathmatch,king of hill, crazy king, 2v2-3v3-4v4 etc) Not including different maps.Thats about 50 people maybe wanting to play with you. Take into consideration about 7 matches in each game mode and you are down to about 7 people trying to do what you are doing. That assumes no1 is afk or goes afk when you are making a match. To be fair, finding a match isnt always all that difficult. It more often than not requires a higher level of patience.Overall 5/10That isnt bad! It is decent, and fun will be had. It is worth a look. It is not your typical game. has its issues, but is solid fun.With actual friends 8.5/10Yes, there is a huge advantage to be had when playing with people you know and generally play games with. This is where the game shines. Plan to play with others, either make friends or get your friends to play with you. but fun will be had.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Guns of Icarus is a game I'd label as "crewed vehicular combat" with a steampunk theme. A crew of players on an airship with many other crews on other airships of both friend and foe. You fight with various manned guns placed on the ship; damaging the enemys' guns, engines, balloon, hull and armor while keeping your own repaired when you can.There's strategy, there's teamwork, there's action. Most of all it's a fresh idea! Don't get me wrong I have nothing against other shooters, but this game does something new;something new is incredibly more worthwhile then another game of something that's already been made when it's good.Sadly this game is on a list of games that's amazing and deserves a lot of attention from many but just doesn't get it. It manages about 300 players at peak times on a weekend right now. While the game is loaded with clans eager to include you to their fleet the game doesn't offer much for the casual player.The lobby in this game is more than a bit sluggish if I'm honest. Everyone can see everyone else's ship and weapon loadouts. So both sides constantly change their loadouts to be the counter to the opponent's loadout. So it's like watching people play "Paper Rock Scissors" but they're allowed to change their decisions and see what the opponent is using. Making it like...Ship 1: RockShip 2: PaperShip 1: ScissorsShip 2: RockShip 1: PaperShip 2: ScissorsShip 1: Rock...for literally ten minutes I usually wait on the captains over this - usually only stopping because the room ran out of time. This is really the only thing I find glaring about this game; the lobby.There's been word for a while about this game getting a Coop and adventure mode. While it isn't out yet that does sound like something that'll get a heavy activity boost. I can't say much about that though other than I'm eager to see it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												ONE SENTENCE REVIEW:Guns of Icarus Online is the spiritual successor to the 2010 game Guns of Icarus, which provides good graphics with fun (albeit somewhat long) cooperative matches, but suffers from a somewhat steep learning curve.  LONG SENTENCE REVIEW:Guns of Icarus Online at first glance looks like a simple game. Man a ship, cooperate with teammates/friends, win game. Its not that simple. First of all there are three classes and from the tutorial they "briefly" teach you the basic mechanics of the game. Sadly though the tutorial may teach you the stuff you need to know but the tutorial doesn't test you for the actual war every match is. Sure there's a Practice Mode, but sadly that doesn't actually prepare you for how tense the matches go (more on this on the latter part of this review). As I have tested the Practice Mode, the game's AI is simply isn't good enough. And I lost my first match because I didn't have a crew and I was given an AI team, so it ended with me inevitably losing the match. So ideally the only way to really experience and prepare yourself for the game is to actually play the "real" matches, and not the practice ones. It would help if you have friends to play with, but going in solo would be somewhat hard since the matches can get really tense. For example there was one match which was 3 v 3, one of my crew members was still new to the game so he frequently manned the guns instead of fixing things (since he was an engineer) and until I helped him and told him to do the things he's already expected to know, we would've lost. It's stuff like this that requires a very detailed tutorial, sadly though the tutorial of the game is very brief and last around 2-5 minutes less.Now lets go to the graphics department. The game looks alright, graphically there's nothing special. But for its visual style it looks nice, I like how the ships and characters look like. Gameplay wise though it's almost as good. Matches range from 2 v 2 to 3 v 3, and contains several maps that looks good. One of the things why I like this game is because It reminds me of one my favorite movies when I was a kid, Treasure Planet since people you're sailing a flying ship excluding the space travelling. And combat wise is great since this is one of the few games I found to be heavily cooperative base. I cannot emphasize this even more. Cooperation is the key to winning every single match, if one of you tries to be a jerk and try and go solo then not only will you fail miserably, you will also ruin the game for everyone else.Yes, I recommend this game because its unique and at the same time fun, provided that you don't mind a somewhat steep learning curve.Now if ever you do get this game I would suggest you buy the collector's edition including: A Costume Pack, and the Game's Soundtrack. Now I'm not suggesting this because I'm paid to, I'm suggesting you to buy this because if you're like me who likes listening to composers such as Hans Zimmer and John Williams, I suggest you buy this collector's edition now. The added costume pack is nice though, but its nothing noteworthy. Truth be told the real gem in this collector's edition would be this OST, so if ever you consider buying this game I'd really recommend the Collector's Edition.(side note: thanks to my friend thebashfulone for getting me the game :D, seriously though get this game if you already haven't I really recommend it)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Guns of Icarus Online is a Steampunk Squad Based Fighter similar to Verdun. You pick from three classes: Pilot, Gunner, or Engineer and you and three of your mates fight in a Team Deathmatch or King of the Hill.For new players I recommend Engineer. Piloting has a steep learning curve, and everyone and their mother goes Gunner. If you master engineering, you will be invited to join many crews and have a better shot at applying for clans.The game requires you to work as a team, not only with your crew but the other ships on your team as well. Failure to work together -WILL- end in your defeat. So having a Microphone is a must if you are to play this game.There are Microtransactions, but only for cosmetics and they can be unlocked through gameplay anyways, so it doesn't feel like they are really there. I highly recommend this game.Graphics are good quality, this doesn't mean realistic, but it means that you do not see pixelation. Cons are: -There is no Singleplayer mode, so you will need a stable internet connection to play. -As always, it is best to play with friends as random players act like this is Rambo and will not work as a team.I rate this game a must play.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
Pros: This game definitely fullfills your Steampunk fetish better than any other multiplayer game out there, including the MMOs.  Despite falling squarely into a heaping pile of Steampunk tropes, the game itself is refreshing & mostly original.  Teamwork is essential on multiple levels - both with your own crewmates and the other ships on your side.  Adding built-in voice chat was a wise choice indeed (It boggles the mind just how many games out there today still expect you to be running TeamSpeak, or whatever, in another channel.)  To my pleasant surprise, the game is remarkably absent the usual armies of drooling blockheads that populate most multiplayer combat sims, and the community is refreshingly non-toxic overall.  Truly a breath of fresh air hiding amongst the fart miasma that is multiplayer competitive gaming in general.  Trolls are a rare signt indeed, and that's a great thing.The graphics are simply stunning, especially for something still running in only 32bits.  There's enough eye-candy here to impress even old vet Skyrim players.  That's not just the skybox, either.  The ships themselves, the crews, the creaking of the hulls, the puttering of the engines.  It's not just pretty pictures - it's a compelte environmental experience that works on every level and at every distance.The game mechanics are mostly well done, and while the constant juggling of weapon & ship values by the developers may seem frustrating, to me that only shows that they still care about their game and are putting forth effort to maintain balance.  The matchmaking system isn't completely broken, which is something that I honestly don't think that I've ever experienced before.Also worth noting is that here is a game that has been out for literally years and to this day all of the microtransactions are still for cosmetic items only.  Think about that.  How many games out there have made it more than six months before they started trying to sell you golden bullets?  I can think of only one, and that's this one.  So major kudos for that.Cons: Map selection is iffy, and no matter what game style you pick it always deteriorates into deathmatch in short order.  While every map creates it's own problems and opportunities, it always boils down to "kill the other guy first" no matter what the actual rules of the match are.  But I suppose that's true everywhere.While people are usually brilliant at coordinating with their own crews, cooperation between ships seems to be lacking outside of "clan" players.  Not sure why.  But that's a people problem; it has nothing to do with the developers, so they're excused on this one.Security against hackers is... questionable.  I've seen some rather improbably things happen far too many times to believe that it was always a coincidence.  I can see someone scoring a critical hit on someone from BVR into a fog cloud with a full speed defelection shot once in a blue moon.  When it happens fifteen times in a row I just log out.  Not dealing with it.The biggest problem is the emphasis on "min/maxing" - a problem that has plagued them since day one and persists to this day.  Simply put, some equipment when places on certain ships in certain positions is simply best and nothing else can compare.  These are not tiny differences, they are major differences.  Because of this, despite all of the tweaking by the devs and the multitude of creative options available, the reality is that every single ship hull in the game has been refined into a single, proven configuration that everybody uses.  Likewise, because of this every single ship uses exactly the same tactics to maximize that one configuration and everyone knows it.  The problem with all of that is that it reduces the vast potential for strategic possibilities into a simple game of "rock, paper, scissors" and the outcome of a match is often determined before it even starts.  I've watched, laughing, as people have tried to "snipe" ship hull/template changes in during the very last second before a match starts.  I know the devs are trying to fix this, but so far... yeah, it's not working.Conclusion: Still a very fun game.  It's beautiful, fairly original, the community is realitively polite, and it has stayed true to it's "buy once, play forever" goal & doesn't try to shove it's microtransactions down your throat.  For that reason it's worth the money even if you don't play that often.  Right now it's only $10 and at that price you're definitely getting more than your money's worth.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												This is my new favorite game. The graphics as far as maps are minimal, yet the details of the ship are quite good. What makes this game is the online gameplay, hence Icarus "online". You play against and with other players from all over thr world in these massive balloon ships equiped with guns and cannons. Your objective is to take out other ships of the opposing tem by working together. This game is your worst nightmare if you can't get a crew to communicate. There are 3 classes: engineer, gunner, and captain. The 3 classes can do everything each class can do, but are more suited towards their trait.  The gunner: easiest class to play... fire and shoot at the enemy team. The engineer: fix broken weapons and engines, while also putting out fires... Most crucial player.  Captain: As you can guess, mans and manuevers the ship into danger and out. Has a few perks that can help escape enemy ships. Player base quality: Harcore players, griefers, and noobs. As in everygame.  One of my favorite things about this game though is character customization. There is a store you can use (costs real money) where you can pimp out your character in hats and all sorts of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Best part is it only costs around 30 cents or less for an item.  So just buy it.... I need people to play with me and yell at russians dudes with me.

All you do is run around clicking systems as they break, over and over, no steam-management type gameplay, no skill involved. Gets real boring and repetitive real fast. Average of 160 players in the last 30 days and dropping steadily according to steamcharts.Only gunner and pilot are fun and take skill but you'll probably never get to play those because everyone will be trying to play gunner and pilot, avoiding boring engineer like the plague. Which is really a shame, because you can't win without an engineer, so you'll probably just end up having to choose between winning and having no fun whatsoever, or losing but at least you got to play gunner/pilot.

												This game is good.The community I believe, is the best part of it; almost all the players are friendly and welcoming. Out of the hundreds of matches I've been in I've only experienced one rather unpleasant individual. The gameplay is incredibly fun, there is a depth to the countless strategies and ways to play the game that are really great. Ship customization allows you to make really interesting builds, you can have a fast sniping ship or a tanky ship with heavy guns. This is one of the few games I always come back to play, it's totally worth it!Pros:+ Fun, intense gameplay+ Incredibly friendly community+ Countless ways to play and strategize+ Great visuals+ Constant new updates + Lots of fun with friendsCons:+ At times can get repetitive+ The matchmaking lobbies drag on forever. A recent update sped it up a bit, but it still takes a good 10-15 minutes to start a match!

												Bought a 4-pack for $20 on sale.Its a 4 Man Team Airship Combat game, where you have a team of 4 players per airship, and up to 4 ships per team. The controls work well and if you have a computer that can run it DirectX 11, it looks amazing. Character Customization, Airship Builds, Clan wars and and excellent community of players ready to blow ships out of the sky. A personal favorite for team-based PVP games.8/10 - Put out about a 1000 fires, still burned to death.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												Please, if you're even slightly interested in this game, stick with me to the end.At first, I was turned off of this game. The in-game cosmetic microtransactions in a paid game, and a couple of friends' opinions of it did not sell it for me. But, when another friend of mine gave me the game so that I could crew on his ships, and I gave it another look...I found my new favorite game.The developers have put in a lot of time, effort, and love into their creation and their community. They're quite involved with the people that play their game, and many if not all of them play their game every chance they get, twice a week.The in-game cosmetic store, let me say, is optional. Nothing you buy will affect your gameplay...AND, any piece in the store can be earned for free in dev matches, hosted Tuesdays and Thursdays, if you're feeling particularly frugal.About the game itself, think of it as "3D naval battles" against other teams of people. Each crew of four works together to man a ship, which is chosen by the captain. Each ship flies differently, and uses different tactics and strategies to be effective. The most important aspects to winning this game are, in my opinion, communication, morale, and teamwork, in that order. Everything else is gravy.Guns of Icarus: Online is seriously underrated, and I hope that everyone gives it a chance. But I must say, it's even better if you have someone to fly with. Bring a friend or two, and you won't regret it!

Hes flying the ship and need to tell the other guys on the ship what to do. You can level up with all the 3 classes whrn you play games. Its a very good teamwork game and come up with many  different ships and different guns on the ship. I'll for sure recommend this game to everyone who loves teamwork games and playing with your friends.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												Not necessarily a game for everyone but I am personally a sucker for these sorts of teamwork games and have been wanting a game where you play as a single crewman on a ship as a multiplayer concept for a while. I was thinking tallship more then airship but no complaints here. The gameplay is simple but I find there is a good deal of strategic depth here with positioning, gun/ship matchups, and time management to keep things engaging. With a weak captain the game can feel pretty bland, but when you have a good talkative crew with plans and a leader suddenly you're playing a completely different game and it has a great feel to it. So far the community has had a really nice air to it and I've been having a ton of fun.On the downside bugs still crop up here and there. Nothing I haven't been able to fix by restarting the client but needing to do so mid match because I couldn't access my tools or use guns was frustrating. Hopefully that sort of thing will get patched up as the game moves forward.The game could end up feeling slow and for some classes you can find yourself behaving fairly mindlessly in your task which could result in finding things boring which is why I mentioned it may not be for everyone. I find that my investment in what is happening on the larger scope keeps me engaged even when I'm just staring out into a dustcloud waiting for the pilot to bring us around but that investment is largely created by the community and having a nice bunch in your crew. I've had some silent rides where I started to feel managing certain guns or covering certain areas as an engineer becoming monotonous. Though with a lively crew this never even occured to me.All in all, I've been having an absolute blast with it. If you like teamwork orientated games and feel you can be invested in a team outcome as much as personal activity you should have a great time here, though a mic is basically a must so do make sure you have one. If your unsure I would lean towards advising you give it a shot as it is a fairly unique sort of game. Even if you grow tired of it eventually I think you'll still find yourself with a good set of fond memories. Sometimes hunting for a good crew can take a bit but hop around and try to chat with people and see what you can find. If your having no luck try and find a Community Ambassador. They've all been great in my experience for getting fun matches rolling.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Guns of icarus online is a super unique and super fun experience. the game is an airship combat game, where you and 3 other people crew an airship and co-ordonate to take down the enemy. For those unwilling or reserved about communicating (specifically verbally but also in text) with your fellow crew members it may be a little hard for you, as this game requires a large amount communication and co-ordonataion to function as each member needs to communcate to take down the enemy, whilst also keeping your own ship airborn.guns of icarus has 3 classes. gunner, engineer and pilot. each pretty much self explanatory as to what they specialize in. each class has different loadouts and skills they can customize to the players liking, along with how they look depending if you're willing to spend more money on cosmetics. Whilst admitably lacking in differing gamemodes besides how many ships can be fighting at a time (i.e 1v1 2v2 etc) the game makes up for it with a good variety of ship and weapon choices and the fact that each battle will mostly likely not play out the same twice. one team may have an upper hand one game but be absolutely stomped the next.If the idea of airship based combat where communication with your crew is key sound good to you, you'll most likely love Guns of icarus. its an excellent game and pretty cheap to boot. 8/10

Posted: February 20, 2014
												Guns of Icarus Online has a wonderful teamwork aspect to it in which most other games don't really provide. Most games have a certain objective and then everyone can go off and do their own thing. With this game, you all have to work together and provide key communication in order to own the skies and take the victory.The game's graphics may not be as high as big brand games, but they sure are detailed enough to get the point across. The engine performs amazingly and I have had no trouble whatsoever in figuring out how to play. The controls are put up on screen (providing you kept the tips on) so that even the most novice of players can get a grip for the controls.Customization is also very big in this game. Not only can you customize your character's appearance, but you can customize your ship down to the last weapon. Want a flamethrower on your vessel? Go right ahead! The game already has a large selection of weapons for you to use so go ahead and use them!All in all this game is great and it really does show in the dynamic of its performance, quality, and playability. The easy controls, stunning design, and almost limitless customization makes this game perfect for those who seek action, and great team playing.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												This game has what a steam punk junkie needs. Well, at least for air-ship to air-ship combat. Play a pilot and fly your ship through the maps and out wit you enemies, or shoot them down as a gunner with any of the veriety of weapons mounted on the ship or, keep your crew alive with one of the most important rolls by bashing parts back together with a wrench as an engineer. This team based game is also just as beautiful as it is spectacularly entertaining. The graphics shine brightly and have a bit of an old timely grain to them as if being watched through an old film projector and on some maps the rain splashes in your eyes obscuring your vision slightly. The best thing about this game is the community though. Developers are constantly online taking notes and playing in matches with the players and the players themselves have been nothing but friendly sore the occasional troll or angry Russian pilot. The game does fall flat on a few things though such as game type veriety and the ungodly A.I. engineers as well as some unbalanced ship builds and the fact that pilots, gunners and engineers have no significant advantage over one another accept for having more equipment for their assigned rolls. In the end the game is under constant change and I hear that more game modes are on the way, as well as maps, ships, guns and most importantly hats.Sk00mathief
